PREAMBLE
         This code of the Village of River Forest, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 3956, passed May 12, 2025. Ordinances
of the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions of this
code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith. Consult
the Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular provision of
the code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
                     American Legal Publishing
                     Cincinnati, Ohio
ORDINANCES PENDING REVIEW FOR CODIFICATION
Listed ordinances have been passed, but they are pending review by the
publisher, and they may not amend the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.
ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 2065
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING
THE VILLAGE CODE OF RIVER FOREST, ILLINOIS
BE IT ORDAINED by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of River
Forest, Illinois, as follows:
   Section 1: That the provisions of the Village Code of the Village of River
Forest, Illinois, prepared by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., under the direction of
the governing body of the Village, containing all ordinances of a general
nature in effect at the time of such codification, shall be in force on and
after the first day of May, 1981, and all ordinances of a general nature in
force on said first day of May, 1981, and not contained in such Code are hereby
repealed from and after the first day of May, 1981, except as hereafter
provided.
   Section 2: There is hereby adopted, as a method of perpetual codification,
the loose-leaf type of binding together with the continuous supplement service,
provided by Sterling Codifiers, Inc., whereby each newly adopted ordinance of a
general and permanent nature amending, altering, adding or deleting provisions
of the Official Village Code is identified by the proper catchline and is
inserted in the proper place in each of the official copies. Each such new
provision shall become effective upon the passage of the ordinance and the
insertion of the proper replacement pages in the copies of the Code, three (3)
copies of which shall be maintained in the office of the Village Clerk,
certified as to correctness and available for inspection at any and all times
that said office is regularly open.
   Section 3: That the repeal provided for in the preceding section of this
ordinance shall not affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty
or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before
the first day of May, 1981; nor shall such repeal affect any ordinance or
resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the Village or
authorizing the issue of any bonds of the Village or any evidence of the
Village's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the Village;
nor shall such repeal affect the administrative ordinances or resolutions of
the President and Board of Trustees not in conflict or inconsistent with the
provisions of such Code; nor shall such repeal affect the annual appropriation
ordinance; nor shall it affect any ordinances levying or imposing taxes; nor
shall it affect any ordinances relative to the salaries and bonds of Village
officers and employees; nor shall it affect any right or franchise conferred by
ordinance or resolution of the Village on any person or corporation; nor shall
it affect any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending or any judgment rendered
on or prior to the first day of May, 1981; nor shall it affect any ordinance
passed after the first day of May, 1981.
   Section 4: All ordinances of a general nature included in this Official
Village Code shall be considered as a continuation of said ordinance provision
and the fact that some provisions have been deliberately eliminated by the
governing body shall not serve to cause any interruption in the continuous
effectiveness of ordinances included in said Official Village Code.
   Section 5: It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to
change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of such Code, or
to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such
Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the Village to be
misrepresented thereby. Any person, firm or corporation violating this Section
shall be punished as provided in Section 1-4-1 of the Village Code of River
Forest, Illinois.
   Section 6: All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are,
to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed.
   Section 7: This ordinance shall go into effect not less than ten days after
publication of such Code.
   Section 8: This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after
its passage, approval and publication as provided by law.
   Passed and approved by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of
River Forest, Illinois, this 23rd day of March, 1981.
                           /s/
                           President
ATTEST:
/s/
Village Clerk
Published in book form March 23, 1981
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATIVE
CHAPTER 1
OFFICIAL VILLAGE CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Code Alteration
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the President and Board, this Village Code is hereby declared
to be and shall hereafter constitute the official Village Code of River Forest.
This Village Code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the RIVER FOREST
VILLAGE CODE, and it is hereby published by authority of the President and
Board and shall be kept up to date as provided in Section
1-1-3  of this Chapter under the direction of the Village Administrator, acting
for said President and Board. Any reference to the number of any section
contained herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same
number, its appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty
clause relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is
made to this Village Code by title in any legal document.
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This Village Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be
received without further proof in all courts and in all administrative
tribunals of this State as the ordinances of the Village of general and
permanent effect, except the excluded ordinances enumerated in Section
1-2-1 of this Code.
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this Village Code shall set forth the title, chapter and
section number of the section to be amended, and this act shall constitute a
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the
amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this Village Code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this Village Code.
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this Village Code in such a manner that
the meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Replacement pages
may be inserted according to the official instructions when so authorized by
the President and Board. The Administrator shall see that the replacement pages
are properly inserted in the official copies maintained in the office of the
Administrator. Any person having in his custody an official copy of this
Village Code shall make every effort to maintain this Code in an up to date and
efficient manner. He shall see to the immediate insertion of new or replacement
pages when such are delivered to him or made available to him through the
office of the Village Administrator. Said Code books, while in actual
possession of officials and other interested persons, shall be and remain the
property of the Village and shall be returned to the office of the Village
Administrator when directed by the President and Board.
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Effect of Repeal of Repealing Ordinances
1-2-3: Severability of Parts of Code
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the Village passed prior to the adoption of this
Village Code are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this Village
Code or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to
the saving clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the
following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy ordinances;
appropriation ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations;
franchise ordinances; ordinances granting special rights to persons or
corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances
establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public places;
improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to elections;
ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the
Village; and all special ordinances.
The provisions appearing in this Code, as far as they are substantially the
same as those of "The River Forest Code of 1931" and "The River Forest Code of
1957", and those of all other ordinances existing at the time of the adoption
of this Code shall be construed as a continuation thereof and not as new
enactments.
1-2-2: EFFECT OF REPEAL OF REPEALING ORDINANCES:
When any ordinance repealing any former ordinance, clause or provision shall be
itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed so as to revive such former
ordinance, clause or provision, unless it shall be therein so expressly
provided.
1-2-3: SEVERABILITY OF PARTS OF CODE:
Should any section, paragraph, sentence, clause, phrase or word of this Code be
declared invalid or unconstitutional by a court of competent jurisdiction, such
invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining words,
phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this Code, since the
same would have been enacted by the President and Board without the
incorporation in this Code of any such invalid or unconstitutional word,
phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section.
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction Of Words
1-3-2: Definitions
1-3-3: Catchlines Of Sections
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this code importing the plural number is
used in describing or referring to any matters, parties or persons, any single
matter, party or person shall be deemed to be included, although distributive
words may not have been used. When any subject matter, party or person is
referred to in this code by words importing the singular number only, or the
masculine gender, several matters, parties or persons and females as well as
males and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included; provided, that these
rules of construction shall not be applied to any section of this code which
contains any express provision excluding such construction or where the subject
matter or content may be repugnant thereto.
The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the village has been
changed in the content of this code to "title", "chapter", "section" and/or
"subsection" or words of like import for organizational and clarification
purposes only. Such change to the village's ordinances is not meant to amend
the passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (1981 Code)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code, they shall have
the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
   ACTION: Shall include suits, prosecutions and all judicial proceedings.
   BOARD: The board of trustees of the village of River Forest, Illinois.
   COMPUTATION OF TIME: The time within which any act provided by law is to be
done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last,
unless the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday, and then it shall also be
excluded. If the day succeeding such Sunday or holiday is also a holiday or a
Sunday, then such succeeding day shall also be excluded.
   COUNTY: Cook County in the state of Illinois.
   FISCAL YEAR: The fiscal year of the village shall begin on May 1 of each
calendar year.
   GENDER: Words importing the masculine gender shall include the feminine and
neuter.
   HOLIDAYS: As used in this code, the following days are considered holidays:
New Year's Day, Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, Presidents' Day, Memorial Day,
Independence Day, Labor Day, Columbus Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day.
   IN THE VILLAGE: The words "in the village" or "within the village" shall
mean and include all territory over which the village now has or shall
hereafter acquire jurisdiction for the exercise of its police powers or other
regulatory powers.
   JOINT AUTHORITY: Words purporting to give a joint authority to three or more
public officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to
a majority of such officers or persons.
   MONTH: A calendar month.
   NUMBER: Words importing the singular number may extend and be applied to
several persons or things and words importing the plural may include the
singular.
   OATH: The word "oath" shall be deemed to include an affirmation and the word
"sworn" shall be construed to include the word "affirmed".
   OCCUPANT OR TENANT: The words "occupant" or "tenant" applied to a building
or land means any person who holds a written or an oral lease of or actually
occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with
others.
   OFFICER: Whenever the title of any village officer is used, it shall be
construed as if the words "of the village of River Forest" followed it.
   OFFICIAL TIME: Central Standard Time shall be the official time within the
village for the transaction of village business; provided, that daylight
savings time shall be used from the last Sunday in April to the last Sunday in
October; provided, that the date and time for advancing and retarding the time
shall be the same as that of the city of Chicago. All legal or official
proceedings of the village board and all official business of the village shall
be regulated as to time in accordance with the provisions of this definition.
When by ordinance, resolution or action of any municipal officer or body, an
act must be performed at or within a prescribed time, it shall be performed
according to the "official time" as herein described.
   OR, AND: "Or" may be read "and", and "and" may be read "or", if the sense
requires it.
   OWNER: The word "owner" applied to a building or land shall include any part
owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant of the whole or a part of
such building or land.
   PERSON: Any individual, partnership, corporation or any city or state or any
subdivision thereof; and includes any trustee, receiver, assignee or personal
representative thereof.
   PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes every species of property, except "real
property" as defined in this section.
   PRECEDING, FOLLOWING: The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before
and next after, respectively.
   PRESIDENT: The president of the village of River Forest.
   PROPERTY: Shall include real and personal property.
   REAL PROPERTY: Shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments and shall
embrace all chattels real.
   SEAL: The seal of the village of River Forest.
   SIDEWALK: That portion of a street between the curb lines, or the lateral
lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines, intended for the use of
pedestrians.
   STATE: The state of Illinois.
   STREET: The entire width between property lines of every way or place of
whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a
matter of right for purposes of traffic.
   TENSE: Words in the present tense include the future.
   VILLAGE: The village of River Forest in Cook County, state of Illinois,
except as otherwise provided.
   WRITTEN, IN WRITING: These terms may include printing and any other mode of
representing words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is
required by law to any official or public writing or bond required by law, it
shall be in the proper handwriting of such person, or in case he is unable to
write, by his proper mark.
   YEAR: A calendar year, unless otherwise expressed. (1981 Code; amd. Ord.
3173, 10-23-2006)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES OF SECTIONS:
The catchlines of the several sections of this code, printed in boldface type,
are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and
shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of
the section, nor unless expressly so provided shall they be so deemed when any
of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (1981
Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty; Continuing Violations
1-4-2: Application Of Provisions
1-4-3: Liability Of Officers
1-4-4: Penalties, Violation Of Certain Code Sections
1-4-5: Penalties For Late Payment Of Annual Inspection And Maintenance Fees
1-4-6: Penalties For Late Payment Of Annual Business, Occupation And Trade
License Fees
1-4-7: Returned Check Fee
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY; CONTINUING VIOLATIONS:
Whenever in this code or in any ordinance of the village any act is prohibited
or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or wherever in such code
or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is
declared to be unlawful where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the
violation of any such provision of this code or any ordinance shall be punished
by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars. A separate offense shall be
deemed committed for each day any violation of any provision of this code or of
any ordinance shall continue. (1981 Code)
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of
this code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this code where any duty
is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any action which is of a
continuing nature is forbidden or is declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or sections of this code, the prosecuting officer may elect
under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the
same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other
penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a
breach of any section or provision of this code and there shall be no fine or
penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this chapter
shall apply. (1981 Code)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the president and board to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (1981 Code)
1-4-4: PENALTIES, VIOLATION OF CERTAIN CODE SECTIONS:
   A.   Penalties: Effective May 1, 2003, the penalties for violation of the
sections of this code, indicated below, shall be twenty dollars if paid before
the due date and thirty five dollars if paid after the due date:
Regulations Violated Code Section

   B.   Parking Violations: (Rep. per correspondence dated 11-10-2008)
   C.   Unauthorized Use: The fine for unauthorized use of accessible parking
spaces shall be two hundred fifty dollars. (Ord. 3184, 1-22-2007)
   D.   Prima Facie Proof: The fact that an automobile which is illegally
operated or parked is registered in the name of a person shall be considered
prima facie proof that such person was in control of the automobile at the time
of such violation. (Ord. 2506, 7-27-1992)
1-4-5: PENALTIES FOR LATE PAYMENT OF ANNUAL INSPECTION AND MAINTENANCE FEES:
The penalty for late payment of the following annual inspection and maintenance
fees required by the sections of this code shall be five dollars if paid more
than thirty days after the billing date, ten dollars if paid more than sixty
days after the billing date, and fifteen dollars if paid more than ninety days
after the billing date:
 
Regulations          Code Section
Sign regulations     4-5-3
Awnings and canopies 4-6-3
Driveways            5-3-2
 
The penalties provided for in this section shall become effective on May 1,
1981. (Ord. 2067, 4-13-1981; amd. Ord. 2668, 2-12-1996)
1-4-6: PENALTIES FOR LATE PAYMENT OF ANNUAL BUSINESS, OCCUPATION AND TRADE
LICENSE FEES:
The penalty for late payment of the following annual business, occupation and
trade license fees required by title 3 of this code shall be ten dollars if
paid more than thirty days after the billing date, twenty dollars if paid more
than sixty days after the billing date, and thirty dollars if paid more than
ninety days after the billing date. (Ord. 2141, 2-13-1984, eff. 5-1-1984; amd.
Ord. 2668, 2-12-1996)
1-4-7: RETURNED CHECK FEE:
A fee of twenty five dollars will be assessed to the remitter for any check
that is returned to the village by its depository due to nonsufficient funds,
closed accounts or insufficient credit. (Ord. 2519, 10-13-1992)
CHAPTER 5
VILLAGE PRESIDENT
SECTION:
1-5-1: Election, Term Of Office
1-5-2: Oath; Bond
1-5-3: Voting Privileges
1-5-4: President Pro Tem; Vote
1-5-5: General Powers And Duties
1-5-6: Compensation
1-5-7: State Of Emergency
1-5-1: ELECTION, TERM OF OFFICE:
The president shall be elected every other odd numbered year for a term of four
years, and shall serve as president of the board as provided by statute. The
date for inauguration of a newly elected president shall be at the beginning of
the regular meeting of the president and board of trustees on the second Monday
of May. (Ord. 3086, 9-27-2004)
1-5-2: OATH; BOND:
The president shall take the oath of office prescribed by statute. He shall
also, before entering upon the duties of his office, execute a bond to the
village in the sum of five thousand dollars, with surety to be approved by the
board, conditioned as required by law. (1981 Code)
1-5-3: VOTING PRIVILEGES:
The president shall vote in case of a tie or where one-half of the trustees
elected have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution or motion, even though
there is no tie vote, or where a vote greater than a majority of the corporate
authorities is required by state statute. (1981 Code)
1-5-4: PRESIDENT PRO TEM; VOTE:
The president pro tem shall vote in his capacity as trustee but shall not be
entitled to another vote in his capacity as president pro tem. (1981 Code)
1-5-5: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Appoint Officers; Sign Permits: The president shall preside at all
meetings of the board, and shall cause to be signed all official documents
issued or granted by authority or order of the board and may revoke the same
for good cause, except where in conflict with law or ordinance. The president
shall make appointments to all nonelective offices, with the advice and consent
of the board.
   B.   Additional Duties: He shall perform all such other duties as are now or
may be hereafter delegated to him by ordinance and law. (1981 Code)
1-5-6: COMPENSATION:
The president shall not receive any compensation for his services as president,
either for attendance at the meetings of the village board or the board of
local improvements, or for the performance of any other duty or thing connected
with said office of president. (1981 Code)
1-5-7: STATE OF EMERGENCY:
   A.   The village president is authorized to declare of a state of emergency
within the village of River Forest based on the following findings and
supporting facts:
      1.   There has occurred, or there is actual imminent danger of occurring,
a natural disaster, catastrophe, pestilence or contagious disease, which is
likely to cause loss of life, loss of productivity, hardship or suffering to
the persons residing in or doing business in the village.
      2.   That the declaration of emergency is necessary in order to prevent
loss of life or injury, alleviate damages, loss, hardship, or suffering.
   B.   During a declared state of emergency, the village president is
authorized to exercise, by executive order, such powers of the village
president and board of trustees as may be reasonably necessary to respond to
the emergency.
   C.   A declaration of a state of emergency shall:
      1.   Be executed under oath.
      2.   Set forth the basis and underlying facts supporting the declaration
of a state of emergency.
      3.   Make reference to published statements of federal, state or county
agencies whose duty it is to address emergency matters.
      4.   To the extent possible, specify the procedures and protocols to be
followed during the state of emergency.
      5.   To the extent possible, make specific reference to any regulations
which may be subject to suspension during the state of emergency.
      6.   Consistent with division C.8. below, set forth the duration of the
state of emergency.
      7.   Be filed with the village clerk as soon as practicable.
      8.   Expire no later than the adjournment of the first regular or special
meeting of the village president and board of trustees after the state of
emergency has been declared.
   D.   A declaration of emergency pursuant to this authority may not suspend
in any way the rights of persons under the Illinois or United States
Constitutions. (Ord. 3800, 3-16-2020)
CHAPTER 6
VILLAGE BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-6-1: Election, Term Of Office
1-6-2: Oath; Bond
1-6-3: Meetings Of The Board
1-6-4: Rules And Order Of Business
1-6-5: Standing Committees
1-6-6: Special Or Ad Hoc Committees
1-6-7: Compensation Of Board Members
1-6-1: ELECTION, TERM OF OFFICE:
The Board shall consist of six members, elected as provided by statute for a
term of four years. This Board shall be the Legislative Department of the
Village government, and shall perform such duties, and have such powers, as may
be authorized by statute. The date for inauguration of newly elected Trustees
of the Village shall be at the beginning of the regular meeting of the
President and Board of Trustees on the second Monday of May. (Ord. 3086, 9-27-
2004)
1-6-2: OATH; BOND:
Members of the Board shall take the oath as prescribed by statute. The Chairman
of the Committee on Finance shall execute a bond to the Village in the sum of
five thousand dollars, with surety to be approved by the Board, conditioned as
required by law. (1981 Code)
1-6-3: MEETINGS OF THE BOARD:
   A.   Regular Meetings: Regular meetings of the President and Board shall be
held at the Village Hall on the second and fourth Monday evenings of each month
at seven o'clock P.M.
   B.   Committee Of The Whole: The Village President and Board of Trustees
shall meet as a Committee of the Whole on the third Monday at seven o'clock
P.M. upon written call of the President, any three or more Trustees or the
Village Administrator. Such call shall specify the matters that will come
before the Board for discussion. Two days' previous notice thereof shall be
given to each member of the Board and the public. The Committee of the Whole
meetings shall be held as a means of exchanging ideas and information between
the administrative staff and the Village Board. As is the case with respect to
other standing committees of the Village Board, such committee may make
recommendations to the full Board at its regular and special meetings.
   C.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be held at any time on written
call of the President or any three or more Trustees; such call shall specify
the business that will come before the meetings and the Village Clerk shall
give two days' previous notice thereof to each member of the Board.
   D.   Place Of Meetings: All meetings of the Board shall be held in the
Village Hall, unless otherwise ordered by the Board.
   E.   Quorum: Four Trustees or the President and three Trustees, shall
constitute a quorum to do business, but a smaller number may adjourn from time
to time and may compel the attendance of absentees.
   F.   Compelling Attendance: If less than a quorum of the Trustees is present
at any regular or special meeting at the time and place designated, such
Trustees may instruct the Village Clerk to send immediate notice to any absent
Trustee that can be found, commanding him to appear forthwith at such meeting.
Any Trustee who shall receive such notice and not obey the same by appearing
forthwith at such meeting as required thereby, without reasonable excuse, shall
be subject to a fine of not more than fifteen dollars for each offense.
   G.   Open Meetings: Meetings of every kind and nature shall be open to the
public, except where specifically exempted by statute. A meeting may be open to
the public and then closed to the public for the purpose of considering matters
specifically allowed to be considered at a closed meeting by statute.
   H.   Closed Meetings: No final action shall be taken at a closed meeting.
Final action on a matter discussed in a closed meeting shall be preceded by a
public recital of the nature of the matter being considered and other
information that will inform the public of the business being conducted. A
verbatim record of all closed meetings in the form of an audio or video
recording shall be made and disposed of as provided by law. Minutes of meetings
closed to the public shall be available only after the Village Board determines
that it is no longer necessary to protect the public interest or the privacy of
an individual by keeping them confidential.
   I.   Conduct Of Meetings Via Electronic Means: The Village Board may provide
for the conduct of its meetings via electronic means, provided no meetings
shall be held via such means until the Board shall have first promulgated rules
therefor. Such rules, as amended from time to time, shall be approved by a
motion of the Village Board. Participation by electronic means shall only be
permitted if a quorum of the Village Board is physically present.
   J.   Public Participation: Any person shall be permitted an opportunity to
address the Village Board at a public meeting during the citizen comments
portion of the public meeting. Comments made are subject to rules established
by the Village Board. (Ord. 3374, 5-23-2011)
1-6-4: RULES AND ORDER OF BUSINESS:
Rule 1. Agenda: Prior to each regular meeting of the Village Board, the Village
Administrator shall cause to be prepared an agenda. Said agenda shall
substantially conform to the following structure:
   I.   Call to order/roll call
   II.   Pledge of Allegiance
   III.   Citizen comments
   IV.   Elected official comments and announcements
   V.   Consent agenda (including minutes)
   VI.   Consent items for separate consideration
   VII.   Recommendations of boards, commissions and committees
   VIII.   Unfinished business
   IX.   New business
   X.   Executive session and any action on executive session items
   XI.   Adjournment
Rule 2. Voting: The ayes and nays shall be taken and recorded in the minutes in
the case of the passage of all ordinances for whatever purpose, and of any
resolution or motion creating a liability against the Village, or for the
expenditure or appropriation of its monies, or at the request of any member. A
concurrence of a majority of all members then holding office on the Village
Board, including the President, shall be necessary to the passage of same,
unless otherwise required by law. In all cases where a motion is entered into
the minutes, the names of the member moving and seconding shall be entered.
In addition, the Village Administrator shall prepare a consent agenda for each
regular meeting containing proclamations, unanimous recommendations of
committees or commissions, resolutions, monthly staff reports or motions which
require only a simple majority vote for passage. The Administrator shall not
include on such agenda any item which requires more than a simple majority vote
for passage. Failure of the President or any Trustee to object to the inclusion
of any item or items on such agenda shall constitute unanimous consent by the
Corporate Authorities to taking a single vote by yeas and nays on the various
items on such agenda. Upon objection by the President or any Trustee to the
inclusion of any item on such agenda, such item shall be removed from the
consent agenda. In the absence of objection or after such removal, the various
items on the consent agenda shall be voted on by the Trustees, and if necessary
the President, in a single vote by yeas and nays. The record of the meeting
shall reflect the names of those voting "yea" and of those voting "nay" with
respect to each item on the consent agenda.
When a question is stated from the Chair, every member present shall vote
therein, unless excused by the President and Board or unless he is personally
interested in the question before the Board. At the conclusion of the roll call
vote, the presiding officer shall announce the results.
Rule 3. Addressing The Board: Except during the portion of the meeting
dedicated to public participation, no person (other than the Village
Administrator or, upon consent of the Board, Village staff) may address the
Board without consent of a majority of the Trustees then present. The public
may address the Board with concerns or comments regarding issues relevant to
Village business. Issues relevant to Village business mean information about
Village events, issues that the Village has the authority to address, items
listed on the agenda and items or issues previously voted on by the Board or
that the Board has the authority to consider or vote on in the future. The
President or her/his designee shall limit comments to matters that are relevant
to Village business. Members of the general public who wish to address the
Board must sign the speaker form. Any person addressing the Board shall be
allotted five minutes to speak.
Rule 4. Rules May Be Suspended: These rules, except rule 2, may be temporarily
suspended by a vote of two-thirds of the Trustees present, but shall not be
repealed, altered or amended, unless notice thereof shall have been in writing,
and alteration and amendment submitted, at least one meeting prior thereto, and
two- thirds of the Trustees shall concur therein.
Rule 5. Expelling A Member: Any member acting or appearing in a disgraceful
manner, or who uses opprobrious or insulting language to or about any member of
the Board, or who does not obey the order of the Chair, shall be, on motion,
censured by a majority vote of the members present, or expelled by a two-thirds
vote of all members elected.
Rule 6. Reconsideration: A vote or question may be reconsidered at any time
during the same meeting, or at the first regular meeting held thereafter. A
motion to reconsider must be made by a Trustee who voted on the prevailing side
of the vote or question to be reconsidered. Any Trustee may second a motion to
reconsider. A vote or question may be reconsidered at a special meeting held
prior to the next regular meeting but only if there are present at such special
meeting as many members of the Board of Trustees as were present when the
original vote was taken. Where a motion to reconsider is made at the same
meeting as the passage of the original motion, it may be postponed to the next
regular meeting. Where a motion to reconsider is to be made at a different
meeting than the original vote, the Trustee intending to make a motion to
reconsider shall inform the President, no more than three business days after
the meeting when the original vote was taken, along with the reason for the
motion to reconsider.
Rule 7. Presiding Officer To Decide: The presiding officer shall decide all
questions of order. In all cases not otherwise provided by law or ordinance,
the Village Board shall be guided by parliamentary law as contained in
"Robert's Rules of Order" and any amendments thereto. (Ord. 3731, 2-25-2019)
1-6-5: STANDING COMMITTEES:
The Village Board may from time to time establish and abolish standing
committees. Said committees shall be comprised of three Trustees as determined
by the consensus of the Trustees. The Chair of each committee shall be
determined by the consensus of the Village Board.
A standing committee shall only hold a meeting to consider a matter within its
jurisdiction, as determined by the Village Board. A standing committee may not
hold a meeting to consider matters outside of its jurisdiction, without the
permission of the Village Board. (Ord. 3757, 5-28-2019)
1-6-6: SPECIAL OR AD HOC COMMITTEES:
Special or ad hoc committees may from time to time be appointed by the Village
Board. Said committees shall serve only until the completion of their
assignment at which time a final written report shall be submitted to the
Board. (Ord. 2269, 11-9-1987)
1-6-7: COMPENSATION OF BOARD MEMBERS:
The members of the Board shall not receive any compensation for their services
as members of the Board, either for attendance at the meetings of the Board or
for the performance of any other duty or thing connected with said Office of
Trustee. (Ord. 2269, 11-9-1987)
CHAPTER 7
VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
SECTION:
1-7-1: Appointment And Term Of Office
1-7-2: Bond, Oath And Compensation
1-7-3: Functional Authority
1-7-4: Coordination Of Departments
1-7-5: Supervision, Duties And Responsibilities
1-7-6: Assistant Village Administrator
1-7-1: APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE:
The Village Administrator, an executive office of the Village, shall be
appointed by the President, by and with the consent of the Board for a term not
to exceed the term of the Village President and until his successor shall be
appointed and qualified. During the temporary absence or disability of the
Village Administrator, the President, by and with the consent of the Board, may
designate some properly qualified person to perform the duties of his office.
(Ord. 3656, 7-10-2017)
1-7-2: BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION:
Before taking office, the Village Administrator shall furnish a bond in such
amount and surety required by the President and Board. He shall take the oath
as prescribed by statute 1 , and he shall receive such compensation as shall be
fixed from time to time by the Board. (1981 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3.
1-7-3: FUNCTIONAL AUTHORITY:
The Village Administrator shall exercise executive and administrative control
over the operating departments of the Village. The Village Administrator shall
be responsible for the operation and administration of all departments. All
department heads will report to the Village Administrator. (1981 Code)
1-7-4: COORDINATION OF DEPARTMENTS:
As Manager for the Village, the Village Administrator is responsible to the
President and Board for coordination of Village departments, representation of
the Village with other governmental bodies, representation of the President and
Board with Village committees and commissions. The Village Administrator may
delegate certain duties, but he may not delegate or relinquish his overall
responsibility for the results and for his accountability to the President and
Board. (1981 Code)
1-7-5: SUPERVISION, DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The Village Administrator shall have the following duties and responsibilities:
   A.   Assist the Board in establishing salary schedules and coordinate and
assist the Board with any employee negotiations.
   B.   Act as the principal public relations executive of the Village.
   C.   Administer the approved personnel policies as established by the Board
and recommend to the Board the selection, promotion, demotion and removal of
any employees of the Village.
   D.   Have responsibility for hiring and firing of all employees, except
department heads, not under the supervision of the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners.
   E.   Be responsible to the Board for administration of Village business,
prepare agendas and record minutes of all meetings of the Board, serve as
Secretary of the Zoning Board of Appeals, see that all required reports are
properly filed with the Federal, State and County authorities, and supervise
all purchasing and approve all bills for payment prior to the submission to the
Board.
   F.   Attend and observe meetings of Village committees and commissions as
may be requested by the Board.
   G.   Recommend and participate in the formulations of new policies and make
decisions within existing policies as they have been approved by the Board. He
will plan, organize, direct and coordinate the staff and programs of the
administration in close concert with department heads, the Village Engineer,
and the Village Attorney and Village Prosecutor.
   H.   Chair and conduct monthly meetings of all department heads (public
works, fire, police) and the Village Finance Director to foster and maintain
effective internal and external relationships and achieve economical,
productive performance.
   I.   Perform such other duties as may from time to time be required of him
by ordinance or resolution of the Board or by direction of the President. (Ord.
3416, 4-9-2012)
   J.   Establish and administer policies and procedures for purposes of
determining whether an employee or former employee is eligible to receive
benefits pursuant to the Public Safety Employee Benefits Act 1 . (Ord. 3478, 3-
11-2013)
 
Notes
1 1. 820 ILCS 320/1 et seq.
1-7-6: ASSISTANT VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR:
   A.   Selection And Employment: An Assistant Village Administrator shall be
selected and employed by the Village Administrator, when such position is
approved by the Board. He shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed
from time to time by the Board.
   B.   General Duties And Responsibilities: Provide staff support to the Plan
Commission and Zoning Board of Appeals.
Advise and assist the Village Administrator with urban planning and economic
development and redevelopment matters.
Advise and assist the Village Administrator with general public relations
matters and the regular publication of a Village newsletter.
Advise and assist the Village Administrator with the evaluation of Village
programs, in specific regard to program efficiency and cost effectiveness.
Advise and assist the Village Administrator in performing his duties and
responsibilities as Budget Officer.
Attend and observe meetings of Village boards, committees, associations and
commissions as may be requested by the village administrator.
Attend and observe meetings of the Oak Park/River Forest chamber of commerce
and the meetings of regional planning and policy bodies, as may be requested by
the village administrator.
Serve as safety director and perform all loss prevention responsibilities
assigned by the village administrator.
Function as acting village administrator in the absence of the village
administrator.
Perform such other duties and responsibilities as delegated to him by the
village administrator in addition to the duties and responsibilities listed
above. (Ord. 2333, 4-10-1989)
CHAPTER 8
VILLAGE CLERK
SECTION:
1-8-1: Election And Term Of Office
1-8-2: Bond
1-8-3: Duty To Prepare Documents
1-8-4: Duty To Record And Publish Ordinances
1-8-5: Additional Powers And Duties
1-8-6: Compensation
1-8-7: Deputy Village Clerk
1-8-1: ELECTION AND TERM OF OFFICE:
The village clerk shall be elected at the consolidated election for president
and shall hold office for a term of four years. The date of inauguration of a
newly elected village clerk shall be at the beginning of the regular meeting of
the president and village board of trustees on the second Monday of May. (Ord.
3086, 9-27-2004)
1-8-2: BOND:
The village clerk shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, execute
to the village a bond in such amount and with surety required by the president
and board. (1981 Code)
1-8-3: DUTY TO PREPARE DOCUMENTS:
The village clerk shall:
   A.   Board Meetings: Attend all meetings of the board and keep a full record
of its proceedings in the journal; keep all records, receive, mark and properly
file all papers coming to this office belonging to the village; grant copies
certified under the corporate seal from the records or papers of the village
and execute such orders as he may receive from the board.
   B.   Prepare Permits And Licenses, Bonds: Prepare and deliver all permits,
licenses and bonds on receipt of the required sums of money therefor. (1981
Code)
   C.   Tax Levy Ordinances: He shall, on or before the second Tuesday in
September, or as required by law, each year, file with the county clerk of Cook
County a certified copy of the tax levy ordinance. (Ord. 2084, 10-12-1981, eff.
5-1-1982)
1-8-4: DUTY TO RECORD AND PUBLISH ORDINANCES:
The village clerk shall, within ten days after they are passed, cause all
ordinances of the village imposing any fine, penalty, imprisonment or
forfeiture, or making any appropriation to be published in such newspapers as
the president and board shall designate; and shall note at the foot of the
record of each ordinance a memorandum of the date of its passage, and the date
of its approval (if approved) by the president, and if published, the date of
such publication. He shall file the original ordinances in his office and
attach a certificate of publication to all ordinances requiring publication.
(1981 Code)
1-8-5: ADDITIONAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Notify Officers Elected Or Appointed: It shall be the duty of the
village clerk, within five days after the result of any election is declared,
or appointment made to notify all persons elected or appointed to any village
office, of their election or appointment, and unless such persons shall qualify
respectively in ten days after such notice, the office shall become vacant.
   B.   Custodian Of Seal And Records: He shall be custodian and keeper of the
corporate seal 1 , and of all books, records, ordinances and papers of the
village, except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance, and shall generally
do and perform such other duties as may be required of him by the president and
board, and by ordinance. (1981 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  1-16-1, "Village Seal", of this title.
1-8-6: COMPENSATION:
The village clerk shall not receive any compensation for services as the
village clerk, either for attendance at the meetings of the board or for the
performance of any other duty or thing connected with the office of village
clerk. (1981 Code)
1-8-7: DEPUTY VILLAGE CLERK:
   A.   Office Created; Appointment: There is hereby created the office of
deputy village clerk in and for the village, who shall perform the duties of
the office of village clerk in the absence or at the direction of the village
clerk. No more than two deputy village clerk positions shall be appointed by
the village clerk and such positions shall hold office at the pleasure of the
village clerk for a term of one year or until successors shall be appointed and
qualified. The appointment shall be made and the village board notified of the
appointments at the time other village officers are appointed. (Ord. 3200, 7-9-
2007)
   B.   Bond: The deputy village clerk shall, before entering upon the duties
of his office, execute a bond to the village in such amount and with such
surety required by the president and board.
   C.   Compensation: The deputy village clerk shall receive such compensation
as the president and board shall from time to time determine. (1981 Code)
CHAPTER 9
VILLAGE FINANCE DIRECTOR
SECTION:
1-9-1: Appointment And Term Of Office
1-9-2: Bond, Oath And Compensation
1-9-3: Duties
1-9-4: Keep Books Of Account
1-9-5: Reports
1-9-6: Village Depositories
1-9-1: APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE:
The Village Finance Director shall be appointed by the President, by and with
the advice and consent of the Board, for a term not to exceed the term of the
Village President and until his or her successor shall be appointed and
qualified. During the temporary absence or disability of the Finance Director,
the President, by and with the advice and consent of the Board, may designate
some properly qualified person to perform the duties of his office. (Ord. 3656,
7-10-2017)
1-9-2: BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION:
Before taking office the Finance Director shall furnish a bond in such amount
and surety required by the President and Board. The Finance Director shall take
the oath as prescribed by statute for a Municipal Treasurer and as prescribed
by statute for a Municipal Comptroller, and he or she shall receive such
compensation as shall be fixed from time to time by the Board. (Ord. 3362, 2-
28-2011)
1-9-3: DUTIES:
The Finance Director shall have the following duties:
   A.   Regarding Village monies:
      1.   Pay Out Monies:
         a.   Keep a true and accurate account of all monies paid into the
treasury, from whom and on what account received.
         b.   Pay out all such sums of money as may be ordered by the President
and Board, and only on checks signed by at least two of the following Village
officials: President, Chairman of the Finance Committee of the Board, Finance
Director, or Administrator.
         c.   Any bond or interest coupon issued by the Village and due and
payable shall be considered as a warrant duly authorized for payment.
      2.   Pay Out Money Only From Appropriate Fund: No money shall be paid by
the Finance Director upon any warrant, bond or coupon except from the monies
belonging to the particular fund or appropriation upon which such warrant shall
have been drawn, nor shall money be transferred from one fund to another after
it has been received by the Finance Director, nor appropriated to any other
purpose than that for which it has been collected or paid, without the vote of
a majority of the Board, unless otherwise provided for by ordinance or law.
      3.   Cancel Paid Warrants: The Finance Director shall cancel all warrants
paid out and redeemed by him or her and, upon the rendering of any monthly
report, the Finance Director shall cause the same to be accompanied by all
warrants, duplicate receipts in detail for all monies received, and such other
vouchers as will fully and entirely cover all his or her transactions for the
month of such report. The Village Clerk shall take charge of the Village
Finance Director's report, warrants and vouchers, and keep the same on file in
his or her office.
      4.   Keep Village Money Separate: The Finance Director shall keep all
monies belonging to the Village in his or her hands separate and distinct from
his or her own monies, and the Village Finance Director is expressly prohibited
from using, either directly or indirectly, the Village money or warrants in his
custody or keeping same for his or her own benefit or that of any person or
persons whatever. Any violation of this provision shall subject the Finance
Director to immediate removal from office by the Corporate Authorities, who may
declare the Finance Director's Office vacant.
   B.   Regarding accounting for Village monies:
      1.   General Powers And Duties: The Finance Director shall exercise a
general supervision over all the officers of the Village charged in any manner
with the receipt, collection or disbursement of the Village revenue, or with
the collection and return of the Village revenue into the treasury. The Finance
Director shall have custody and control of all Village documents, books and
papers which the Corporate Authorities may designate.
      2.   Tax Levy Ordinance: The Finance Director shall assist the Village
Clerk in preparation of the tax levy ordinance.
      3.   Designation Of Person To Sign Instruments: The Finance Director may
designate, in writing, one or more persons who shall have authority to affix
his or her signature as Finance Director to any written instrument which is
required to be signed by the Finance Director. When the Finance Director's
signature is so affixed to a written instrument at the Finance Director's
direction, the instrument, in all respects, shall be as binding on the Village
as if signed by the Finance Director in person. When the Finance Director
designates a person for this purpose, however, he or she shall notify the
President and Board to that effect and state in the notice the specific
instruments which he or she has authorized the person to sign.
      4.   Records Of Bonds Issued By Village: The Finance Director shall keep
in his or her office, in books used solely for that purpose, a correct list of
all the outstanding bonds of the Village, showing the number and amount of
each, and for and to whom the bonds were issued. When Village bonds are
purchased, paid or canceled, these books shall show these additional facts. In
his or her annual report the Finance Director shall describe, particularly, the
bonds sold during the year, and the terms of sale, with every item of expense
incurred therein.
      5.   Coordinate Financial Activities: The Finance Director shall control
and coordinate financial activities to assure fulfillment of operating budgets
for each department, approve operating plans, and assure efficient management
throughout the Village. He or she will carry out such contracts and commitments
as may be authorized by the Board.
      6.   Use Of Investments: The Finance Director shall assure the optimum
use of investment, detect and prevent inadvisable use of allotted funds, and
foster the best use of facilities in the interest of the Village.
      7.   Budgetary Control: The Finance Director shall assure budgetary
control throughout the Village, and, for any commitment of expenditure in
excess of the amount budgeted, obtain the approval from the Budget Officer or
submit the item in question to the Board for its approval.
      8.   Review Audit Reports: The Finance Director shall review all audit
reports of the Village and be available for consultation with any of the
auditors with respect to any matters arising out of such audits, and take all
appropriate action indicated by such audit reports.
   C.   The Finance Director shall perform such other duties as may be
prescribed by ordinance or law for a Municipal Treasurer and for a Municipal
Comptroller, including, but not limited to, such provisions in the Illinois
Municipal Code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-35-5 et seq., as amended.
(Ord. 3362, 2-28-2011)
1-9-4: KEEP BOOKS OF ACCOUNT:
   A.   General: The books which must be kept by the Finance Director shall at
all times show the amounts of monies in his or her custody, amounts received
and amounts paid out. The Finance Director shall, upon receipt of all monies,
deposit same in the appropriate bank accounts as provided by law or ordinance.
   B.   Special Assessments: The Finance Director shall keep records pertaining
to receipts and disbursements applicable to special assessments in such form as
to permit cross reference to the detailed records maintained by the Village
Clerk. The amounts so received shall be held as a Trust Fund and applied only
to payment for the improvement for which the assessment was made, or for
principal and interest on bonds issued therefor, and for no other purpose
except as may be provided by law or ordinance. (Ord. 3362, 2-28-2011)
1-9-5: REPORTS:
   A.   Monthly Reports: The Finance Director shall, at the end of every month,
and more often if required, render an account to the Board, under oath, showing
his or her receipts and disbursements in detail during the month and the state
or condition of every account not closed on his or her books.
   B.   Annual Report: The Finance Director shall, annually, prior to October
15, make out and file with the Village Clerk a full and detailed account of all
Village receipts and expenditures, and of all his or her transactions as
Finance Director during the preceding fiscal year, which account the Clerk
shall cause to be published within ten days, as required by State law. (Ord.
3362, 2-28-2011)
1-9-6: VILLAGE DEPOSITORIES:
   A.   Naming: Alliance Financial Credit Union, Amalgamated Bank of Chicago,
Banco Popular, Bank of America, Charter One Bank, Chase, Citibank, Community
Bank of Oak Park and River Forest, Edward Jones, Fifth Third Bank, Forest Park
National Bank, Harris Bank, Leaders Bank, MB Financial, Suburban Bank & Trust,
TD Waterhouse, UBS, U.S. Bank, Wells Fargo Bank, and the Illinois Funds are
hereby designated as the depositories of Village money. Said depositories shall
disburse said money upon checks as provided for in subsection
1-9-3A of this chapter and as provided by law.
   B.   Compliance With State Law: The said depositories shall, before any
money is deposited, comply with all provisions required of them by law. (Ord.
3362, 2-28-2011)
CHAPTER 10
VILLAGE COMPTROLLER
(Rep. by Ord. 3362, 2-28-2011)
CHAPTER 11
VILLAGE ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-11-1: Appointment And Term Of Office
1-11-2: Bond, Oath And Compensation
1-11-3: General Duties
1-11-4: Attorney For Board Of Local Improvements
1-11-5: Employment Of Special Counsel
1-11-1: APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE:
The Village Attorney shall be appointed by the President, by and with the
advice and consent of the Board, for a term not to exceed the term of the
Village President and until his successor shall be appointed and qualified.
(Ord. 3656, 7-10-2017)
1-11-2: BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION:
Before taking office, the Village Attorney shall furnish a bond in such amount
and surety required by the President and Board. He shall take the oath as
prescribed by statute, and he shall receive such compensation as shall be
fixed, from time to time, by the Board. (1981 Code)
1-11-3: GENERAL DUTIES:
The Village Attorney shall:
   A.   Conduct Law Business Of Village: Superintend and conduct all the law
business of the Village, except such law business delegated to the Village
Prosecutor by the President and Board.
   B.   Draw Ordinances, Leases:
      1.   Draw such ordinances as may be required of him by the President and
Board, or by any committee thereof.
      2.   Draw the leases, deeds, papers and all contracts for the Village,
and when required, furnish written opinions on subjects submitted to him by the
President and Board. (1981 Code)
1-11-4: ATTORNEY FOR BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS:
The Village Attorney shall act as the Attorney for the Board of Local
Improvements 1 . He shall attend all meetings of the Board of Local
Improvements and supervise the keeping of a record of the minutes of said
meeting. He shall prepare or supervise the preparation of all necessary
instruments, resolutions, minutes of meetings, notices, preparation of records,
recommendations, estimates and ordinances, in connection with any proposed
local improvement, and shall prepare all contracts and contractor's bonds. It
shall be his duty to institute all court proceedings in connection with the
levying of special assessments or special tax proceedings for all local
improvements, and prosecute said proceedings to their conclusion. He shall
receive additional compensation for work in connection with local improvements,
as the President and Board shall determine, based upon the fair and reasonable
values of his services. (1981 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 2 of this Code.
1-11-5: EMPLOYMENT OF SPECIAL COUNSEL:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as prohibiting the Board from
employing the Village Attorney or any other attorney as special counsel to
represent the Village from time to time, and to pay such compensation to the
special counsel as the Board may, from time to time, determine. (1981 Code)
CHAPTER 12
DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS
SECTION:
1-12-1: Appointment And Term Of Office
1-12-2: Bond, Oath And Compensation
1-12-3: General Powers And Duties
1-12-4: Records
1-12-1: APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE:
The Director of Public Works shall be appointed by the President, by and with
the advice and consent of the Board, for a term not to exceed the term of the
Village President and until his successor shall be appointed and qualified. The
Village Administrator shall serve as ex-officio Director of Public Works in the
event of a vacancy or absence from this office. (Ord. 3656, 7-10-2017)
1-12-2: BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION:
Before taking office, the Director of Public Works shall furnish a bond in such
amount and surety required by the President and Board. He shall take the oath
as prescribed by statute, and he shall receive such compensation as shall be
fixed from time to time by the Board. (Ord. 3656, 7-10-2017)
1-12-3: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Director of Public Works shall have supervision and maintenance of the
Department of Public Works and shall perform the following duties:
   A.   Control and supervision over water supply, all water equipment and all
water distribution; all sewers and work in connection therewith, and all other
public utilities owned by the Village.
   B.   Inspection of streets, alleys, sidewalks and all other public
improvements.
   C.   Changes in and inspection of existing public utilities and new public
utilities which may be authorized.
   D.   Collection of all refuse and garbage, and the disposal of same.
   E.   Oversight and management of the Village's engineering function and
Village Engineer.
   F.   In all public improvements, he shall inspect the work as it progresses
and approve the installation before payment is made on account of work done,
and he shall be responsible for the maintenance of work so approved.
   G.   Perform such forestry services as assigned.
   H.   Perform such other duties as assigned. (Ord. 3656, 7-10-2017)
1-12-4: RECORDS:
The Director of Public Works shall:
   A.   Preserve in his office all records, including engineering field notes,
maps and plans, and index same.
   B.   Maintain in his office a complete atlas of all sewers laid or connected
in the Village, with all junctions and house connections distinctly recorded
therein.
   C.   Maintain the geographical information system (GIS) of the Village.
(Ord. 3656, 7-10-2017)
CHAPTER 13
HEALTH COMMISSIONER
SECTION:
1-13-1: Appointment And Term Of Office
1-13-2: Bond, Oath And Compensation
1-13-3: General Powers And Duties
1-13-4: Records
1-13-5: Monthly Report
1-13-1: APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE:
The Health Commissioner shall be appointed by the President, by and with the
advice and consent of the Board, for a period of one year and until his
successor shall be appointed and qualified. The Health Commissioner shall be a
resident of the Village. He shall have such assistants as the President and
Board may provide. (1981 Code)
1-13-2: BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION:
Before taking office, the Health Commissioner shall furnish a bond in such
amount and surety required by the President and Board. He shall take the oath
as prescribed by statute, and he shall receive such compensation as shall be
fixed from time to time by the Board. (1981 Code)
1-13-3: GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Health Commissioner shall:
   A.   Have the management and control of all matters and things pertaining to
the Health Department.
   B.   Have and exercise a general supervision over the sanitary condition of
the Village. All orders and directions emanating from the Health Department
shall be issued in the name of the Health Commissioner.
   C.   Give to the President and the officers in charge of all other
departments all such professional advice and information as they may require
with a view to the preservation of the public health, and whenever they shall
hear of the existence of any contagious or pestilential disease, he shall
investigate the same and adopt measures to arrest its progress.
   D.   Enforce all the laws of the State, provisions of this Code and other
ordinances of the Village relating to health, and cause all nuisances affecting
the sanitary condition of the Village to be abated with all reasonable
promptness. For the purpose of carrying out the foregoing requirements, he and
any representative of the Health Department shall be permitted at all times to
enter into any house, store or other building and to cause the floors to be
raised, if he shall deem it necessary, in order to make a thorough examination
of cellars, vaults, sinks or drains and other parts of the building, and to
cause all dead animals or other unwholesome things or substances to be removed.
He shall be authorized to close immediately any store which sells to the
public, if health conditions, in his opinion, so warrant. (1981 Code)
1-13-4: RECORDS:
It shall be the duty of the Health Commissioner to cause to be kept a record of
all transactions of his office, including such statistical information as may
be necessary for the efficient working of his office. (1981 Code)
1-13-5: MONTHLY REPORT:
The Health Commissioner shall, monthly on or before the second Monday, send to
the President and Board a full and comprehensive statement of all matters
pertaining to his office. (1981 Code)
CHAPTER 14
VILLAGE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
SECTION:
1-14-1: Officers Of The Village
1-14-2: Oath Of Office
1-14-3: Bonds Of Officers
1-14-4: Qualify For Office
1-14-5: Records And Documents Of Officers
1-14-6: Board May Require Other Duties
1-14-7: Compensation
1-14-1: OFFICERS OF THE VILLAGE:
   A.   Elected Officers: The elected officers of the Village are a President,
a Board of six Trustees, a Library Board of six Directors and a Village Clerk.
(1981 Code)
   B.   Appointed Officers: The other officers of the Village shall be
appointed by the President and Board at its first regular meeting in the month
of May in each year, or as soon thereafter as may be, and shall hold their
offices as hereinafter provided and until their successors are appointed and
qualified. Any officers so appointed may be suspended or removed from office
for good and sufficient cause, and all vacancies may be filled by said
President and Board. Said appointed officers may consist of a Village
Administrator, a Health Commissioner, Village Attorney, Village Finance
Director, Director of Public Works, Fire Chief, Chief of Police, and Village
Prosecutor. The President and Board may also, from time to time, appoint such
other officers as they may deem necessary. (Ord. 3656, 7-10-2017)
1-14-2: OATH OF OFFICE:
Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, all officers of
the Village, whether elected or appointed, shall take and subscribe to the
following oath:
"I do solemnly swear (or affirm, as the case may be) that I will support the
Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of
Illinois, and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of
           according to the best of my ability."
Such oath or affirmation so subscribed shall be filed in the Office of the
Village Clerk. (1981 Code)
1-14-3: BONDS OF OFFICERS:
Each official bond with surety, as required by the President and Board, shall
be conditioned for the faithful and legal performance of the duties of the
officer giving the bond, and for the payment of all public monies received by
him, according to law 1 , and for a compliance with the ordinances, orders and
resolutions of the Board; provided, that no Village officer shall be accepted
as surety on the bond to the Village. All premiums on official bonds required
by this Code for Village officers or employees shall be paid by the Village.
(1981 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3.
1-14-4: QUALIFY FOR OFFICE:
No officer shall enter upon the duties of his office until he has given bond as
required by this chapter, and if he shall not take oath and present such bond
to the Village Clerk within ten days after notification by the Clerk of his
election or appointment, his office shall be deemed vacant. (1981 Code)
1-14-5: RECORDS AND DOCUMENTS OF OFFICERS:
All books, papers, vouchers, warrants, entries, accounts and memoranda of each
and every officer may be examined at any time by the President or any member of
the Board. The Board may, by resolution, call upon any officer to make a
report, in writing, on any subject matter which said Board may designate in
such resolution and within such time as said resolution may prescribe.
Any person having been an officer of the Village shall, within five days after
notification and request, deliver to his successor in office all money,
property, books and effects of every description in his position belonging to
the Village or pertaining to said office. (1981 Code)
1-14-6: BOARD MAY REQUIRE OTHER DUTIES:
Each officer, besides the specific duties which he may be required to do by the
various provisions of the ordinances of the Village and the State law, shall
also perform such other and further duties and be subject to such other rules
and regulations as the Board may, from time to time, require. (1981 Code)
1-14-7: COMPENSATION:
Compensation shall be as provided by the Village in its annual budget. (1981
Code)

1-15-2: Record and Memorandum of Ordinances

1-15-1: ENACTING STYLE OF ORDINANCES 1 :
The enacting style of all ordinances shall be: "Be it ordained by the President
and Board of Trustees of the Village of River Forest, Illinois, as follows:",
and all ordinances passed by the Board must be signed by the President or by
the President Pro Tem. (1981 Code)

1 1. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-2.
1-15-2: RECORD AND MEMORANDUM OF ORDINANCES 1 :
The Village Clerk shall record, in a book used exclusively for that purpose,
all ordinances passed by the Board. Immediately following such ordinance, the
Village Clerk shall make a memorandum of the date of the passage and the
publication, where required, of the ordinance. The record and memorandum herein
required or a certified copy thereof shall be prima facie evidence of the
contents, passage and of the publication or posting of ordinances. (1981 Code)
 
Notes
1 2. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-5.
1-15-3: PROOF OF ORDINANCES 1 :
The contents of all Village ordinances, the date of passage and the date of
publication or posting, where required, may be proved by the certificate of the
Village Clerk, under the Seal of the Village.
Whenever Village ordinances are printed in book or pamphlet form, and purport
to be published by authority of the Board, such book or pamphlet shall be prima
facie evidence of the contents, passage and legal publication of such
ordinances, as of the dates mentioned in such book or pamphlet, in all courts
and administrative tribunals. (1981 Code)
 
Notes
1 3. S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-6.
1-15-4: PRICE AND COST OF COPIES OF ORDINANCES:
Whenever an ordinance imposing any fine, penalty, imprisonment or forfeiture,
or making any appropriation shall be printed in book or pamphlet form,
published by authority of the Board, the Village shall impose a reasonable
price commensurate with the cost of the printing thereof for the distribution
of such book or pamphlet to the public. (1981 Code)

CHAPTER 22
BUDGET POLICY
SECTION:
1-22-1: Budget Officer And Budget Procedures
1-22-2: Powers And Duties Of Budget Officer In Implementing Budget Policy
1-22-3: Compilation And Contents Of Budget
1-22-4: Passage Of Annual Budget, Effect
1-22-5: Capital Improvement Or Replacement Fund
1-22-6: Revision Of Annual Budget
1-22-7: Funds For Contingency Purposes
1-22-8: Public Inspection, Notice And Hearing On Budget
1-22-9: Purchasing
1-22-10: Property Tax Cap
1-22-11: Travel Expense Control
1-22-1: BUDGET OFFICER AND BUDGET PROCEDURES:
   A.   Statutes Adopted: The village hereby adopts 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/8-2-9.1 through and including 5/8-2-9.10, providing for an annual
municipal budget in lieu of the passage of an annual appropriation ordinance.
   B.   Budget Officer:
      1.   Appointment: The village president with the approval of the board of
trustees, shall appoint a budget officer who shall have the powers, duties and
responsibilities enumerated in the above sections of the Illinois Compiled
Statutes as they are now, or may hereafter be amended.
      2.   Bond: The budget officer shall furnish a bond in such amount and
surety required by the president and board, or such other sum as may be
required by statute.
      3.   Removal From Office: The budget officer may be removed for cause at
any time by the president and board of trustees voting jointly. The action of
the president and board of trustees in removing the budget officer shall be
final.
   C.   Preliminary Budget: Copies of the preliminary annual budget shall be
made available for public inspection in typewritten form in the office of the
village clerk for at least ten days prior to the passage of the annual budget,
and not less than one week after the budget is available for inspection, and
prior to final action on the budget, at least one public hearing shall be held
on the budget by the president and board of trustees. Notice of this hearing
shall be given by publication in a newspaper having general circulation in the
village at least one week prior to the time of the hearing.
   D.   Budget Revisions:
      1.   Authority: The board of trustees may delegate authority to the
village administrator, budget officer or finance director to delete, add to, or
change items previously budgeted to the department, board or commission,
subject to such limitation or requirement for prior approval by board of
trustees, upon a two- thirds vote of members, may establish. The budget officer
may revise or alter the annual budget by changing line items in the same
department category or same fund without board approval.
      2.   Vote On Revisions: The annual budget may be revised by a vote of
two-thirds of the board of trustees by deleting, adding to or changing budgeted
items. Changes made pursuant to subsection D1 of this section shall not be
considered revisions to the annual budget.
      3.   Restrictions On Revisions: No revision of budget items shall be made
which result in increasing the total budget unless funds are available to
effectuate the purpose of the revision.
      4.   Emergency Budget Revisions; Borrowing Money:
         a.   Notwithstanding the limitation of this section, the president and
board of trustees, by two-thirds vote, may make emergency revisions to the
annual budget for: 1) improvements or restorations made necessary by any
casualty or accident; 2) to meet any unforeseen emergency requiring immediate
action to prevent the spread of disease or avoid imminent danger to persons or
property.
         b.   Should any judgment be obtained against the village, the village
may borrow a sufficient amount to pay the same for a space of time expiring not
later than the close of the next fiscal year, which sum and interest shall, in
like manner, be added to and included in the amount authorized to be raised in
the general tax levy of the next year. (Ord. 3361, 2-28-2011)
1-22-2: POWERS AND DUTIES OF BUDGET OFFICER IN IMPLEMENTING BUDGET POLICY:
The budget officer shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   Permit, encourage and establish the use of efficient planning,
budgeting, auditing, reporting, accounting and other fiscal management
procedures in all municipal departments, commissions and boards.
   B.   Compile an annual budget in accordance with 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/8-2-9.3 and this code.
   C.   Examine all books and records of all municipal departments, commissions
and boards which relate to monies received by the village, village departments,
commissions and boards and paid out by the village, village departments,
commissions and boards; debts and accounts receivable; amounts owed by or to
the village, village departments, commissions and boards.
   D.   Obtain such additional information from the village, village
departments, commissions and boards as may be useful for purposes of compiling
a village budget, such information to be furnished by the village, village
departments, commissions and boards in the form required by the budget officer.
   E.   Establish and maintain such procedures as shall ensure that no
expenditures are made by the village, village departments, commissions or
boards except as authorized by the budget. (Ord. 3361, 2-28-2011)
1-22-3: COMPILATION AND CONTENTS OF BUDGET:
The budget shall contain estimates of revenues available to the village for the
fiscal year for which the budget is drafted, together with recommended
expenditures for the village and all of the village's departments, commissions
and boards. Revenue estimates and expenditure recommendations shall be
presented in a manner which is in conformity with good fiscal management
practices. The budget shall contain actual or estimated revenues and
expenditures for the two years immediately preceding the fiscal year for which
the budget is prepared. Each budget shall show the specific fund from which
each anticipated expenditure shall be made. (Ord. 2084, 10-12-1981, eff. 5-1-
1982)
1-22-4: PASSAGE OF ANNUAL BUDGET, EFFECT:
Passage of the annual budget by majority vote of the president and members of
the board shall be in lieu of passage of an appropriation ordinance. The annual
budget need not be published except in a manner provided for in section
1-15-3 of this title. The annual budget shall be adopted by the corporate
authorities before the beginning of the fiscal year to which it applies.
Subsequent to the passage of the budget, an ordinance shall be passed
establishing the property taxes to be levied for the fiscal year. This
ordinance shall establish the property tax as provided for in the approved
budget, and as governed by applicable statutes. (Ord. 2084, 10-12-1981, eff. 5-
1-1982)
1-22-5: CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT OR REPLACEMENT FUND:
Monies may be accumulated in a separate fund for the purpose or purposes of
specific capital improvements or replacements of specific types of municipal
equipment or other tangible property, both real and personal, to be designated
as the "capital improvement or replacement fund". Expenditures from the capital
improvement or replacement fund shall be budgeted in the fiscal year in which
the capital improvement or replacement will occur. Should any surplus monies
remain after the completion or abandonment of any project for which the capital
improvement or replacement fund was inaugurated, then such funds no longer
necessary for capital improvement or replacement shall be transferred into the
general operating fund of the village during the first quarter of the fiscal
year following such abandonment, completion or discovery of surplus funds.
(Ord. 2084, 10-12-1981, eff. 5-1-1982)
1-22-6: REVISION OF ANNUAL BUDGET:
During the first thirty days of a fiscal year and after newly elected officials
have been installed, by a two-thirds majority vote of corporate authorities
then holding office, the annual budget for the village may be revised by
deleting, adding to, changing or creating subclasses within object classes and
object classes themselves.
During the remainder of the fiscal year, the budget officer shall recommend
revisions to the budget for the village by deleting, adding to, changing or
creating subclasses within object classes and object classes themselves.
Revisions requested by department heads, boards or commissions shall be
submitted in writing to the budget officer. The line item amount to be changed
in the budget and the reason therefor shall be clearly stated. The budget
