are outside the limits as described herein, upon application, the village
administrator shall have the authority to vary the permitted hours to
accommodate the activities of such special event, taking into consideration the
impact of such special event on the village's resources and property. (Ord.
3472, 1-14-2013)
8-12-6: CONSIDERATION FOR ISSUANCE; DENIAL:
In determining whether to approve a special event permit, the village
administrator shall consider the following factors relevant to the proposed
special event and necessary to secure the public welfare:
   A.   Whether village resources or property will be affected, or are
reasonably expected to be affected;
   B.   Whether the special event appears to be held for any unlawful purpose;
   C.   Whether it appears the special event may be conducted in a manner so as
to cause a breach of peace;
   D.   Whether the special event will unnecessarily interfere with the public
use of the streets, sidewalks, open and/or public areas;
   E.   Whether the special event may have some special right or priority under
the law; and
   F.   Whether the special event would, in any way, be detrimental to the
public health, safety and welfare.
If the village administrator denies an application for a proposed special
event, the applicant may appeal that decision to the village president and
board of trustees by filing a written appeal of the village administrator's
decision with the village clerk within thirty days of the village
administrator's denial thereof. A majority of the village president and board
of trustees may overturn the village administrator's decision to deny an
application for a special event. (Ord. 3472, 1-14-2013)
8-12-7: RESTRICTIONS AND CONDITIONS:
The permit evidencing approval of a special event may include reasonable time,
place and manner restrictions as a condition to granting any permit if such
restrictions are reasonable and necessary for the protection of the public's
health, safety and welfare. (Ord. 3472, 1-14-2013)
8-12-8: PROHIBITED CONDUCT:
   A.   No person shall knowingly participate in a special event for which a
permit application has been falsified or has not been obtained.
   B.   No person shall continue to organize, or participate in the further
planning or organizing, of a special event that is conducted without a permit
after a permit has been denied.
   C.   No person in a position of influence or control over a special event
shall allow the conduct of a special event without a permit.
   D.   No person shall violate any condition of a special event permit.
   E.   No person shall violate any ordinance, rule or regulation of the
village during the planning, operation or conclusion of a special event. (Ord.
3472, 1-14-2013)
8-12-9: FINES AND PENALTIES:
   A.   In addition to any and all additional remedies available by law, any
person violating any provision of this chapter may be directed to:
      1.   Cease and desist such violation; and
      2.   Upon a finding of liable of this chapter, pay a civil penalty not
less than one hundred dollars nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars for
each violation.
   B.   Every day a violation continues shall constitute a separate and
distinct offense. (Ord. 3472, 1-14-2013)
CHAPTER 13
PARK REGULATIONS
SECTION:
8-13-1: Territorial Jurisdiction
8-13-2: Enforcement
8-13-3: Park Hours
8-13-4: Permits
8-13-5: Protection Of Property
8-13-6: Protection Of Natural Resources
8-13-7: Domestic Dogs And Cats
8-13-8: Vehicles
8-13-9: Bicycles, Skateboards, Rollerblades
8-13-10: Sports And Games
8-13-11: Winter Sports
8-13-12: Personal Conduct
8-13-13: Hindering Or Bribing Employees
8-13-14: Advertising And Vending
8-13-15: Fires
8-13-16: Additional Or Temporary Rules And Regulations
8-13-17: Fines
8-13-1: TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply and be effective in and for all
grounds, buildings and territory, from time to time owned, occupied, or used by
the River Forest park district, Cook County, Illinois, all and every part of
which is hereinafter referred to as the "park district". (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-2: ENFORCEMENT:
The qualified persons who may enforce the park district's rules and regulations
prescribed by this chapter include state and local law enforcement officers and
officers and employees of the park district, including the park board of
commissioners, the executive director of the park district ("director") and
park district employees acting under the director's authority. Arrest powers
are reserved to law enforcement authorities, including members of the River
Forest police department, members of the Cook County sheriff's department, and
the Illinois state police. (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-3: PARK HOURS:
Subject to restrictions on certain activities hereinafter set out, the park
system shall be open for public use between the hours of six o'clock A.M.,
prevailing local time, and dusk each day of the year, and no person shall enter
upon, or in any manner, use any part of the park system between dusk and six
o'clock A.M., prevailing local time, except that those portions of the park
system lighted for recreational use by the public may be used during such time
as they are lighted. (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-4: PERMITS:
No person shall conduct, operate, present, manage, or take part in the
following activities in a park, unless a permit is obtained from the director
prior to the activity:
   A.   Any athletic field used for more than eight persons. The River Forest
park district athletic field use policy is expressly incorporated by reference
into this chapter as if fully stated herein.
   B.   Any picnic, outing, or gathering sponsored by any persons or
organization, or composed of twenty or more persons.
   C.   Any fundraising activity, organized sporting event, fair, children's
program or camp, ceremony, dramatic or musical performance, motion picture,
radio or television broadcast, or public meeting, assembly or parade,
including, but not limited to, rallies, picketing, marches, or political
meetings.
   D.   Sell or offer for sale any goods or services.
   E.   The use of any park or facility by a certain person or group to the
exclusion of others.
Permits are not transferable without written consent of the director, and fees
paid are nonrefundable.
Permits must be applied for at least four weeks in advance of the event, but no
permit shall be issued in excess of twelve weeks prior to the date of the
event.
No person in a park or on park premises shall refuse or fail to produce and
exhibit any written permit if he claims to have upon request of any law
enforcement officer, authorized park district representative, or employee who
wishes to inspect the permit for the purpose of determining that the provisions
of this chapter have been complied with. (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-5: PROTECTION OF PROPERTY:
No person shall, in connection with any property of the park district:
   A.   Destroy, deface, paint, or remove any monument, sign, plaque, stake or
post designating any boundary line, survey line or reference point.
   B.   Cut, break, mark upon, or otherwise damage, destroy, or remove any
building, shelter, lamppost, post, flagpole, storage box, picnic table, bench,
garbage can, paving or paving materials, utility outlet, or other park property
without written permission of the director.
   C.   Deface, destroy, cover, damage, or remove any sign, or place card, or
parts thereof, whether permanent or temporary, posted or exhibited by the park
district to announce the rules, regulations, and warning, or any other
information to the public necessary or desirable for proper use of park or park
property.
   D.   Construct or erect any building or structure of any kind, whether
permanently or temporarily, or run or string any public utility into, upon, or
across a park, without the written permission of the director.
   E.   Enter into or upon any park area or structure closed or posted against
trespass, without written permission of the director. These structures or areas
may be, but are not limited to, construction areas, workshops or stations,
equipment and storage structures or area, or areas hazardous to public safety
or health.
   F.   Tamper with in any way, enter or climb upon, weaken, destroy, damage,
or remove anything from any park vehicle, machine, or implement.
   G.   Misuse any refuse container or receptacle by depositing into it any hot
coals or other hot or burning substances, or by depositing into any garbage,
trash, refuse, pet waste, or other unwanted material that was not gathered on
the site in the course of normal, lawful use of park facilities.
   H.   Bring into, leave behind, or dump any material of any kind, whether
waste or otherwise, in the park, except refuse, ashes, garbage, and other
material arising from the normal use within the park system, provided such
material is properly deposited in receptacles provided for such purposes. (Ord.
3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-6: PROTECTION OF NATURAL RESOURCES:
No person shall, in connection with any property of the park district:
   A.   Cut, remove, uproot, pick, saw, chop, carve, injure or wantonly destroy
any tree, bush, shrub, flower or plant, whether alive or dead, or chip, blaze,
box, girdle, trim, or otherwise deface or injure any tree, shrub or bush, or
break or remove any branch or foliage thereof, or pick or gather any seed of
any tree or other plant, unless necessitated by the performance of restorative
maintenance construction work pursuant to contract with the park district.
   B.   Drive any nail, staple, or attach or fasten any wire, rope, or device
to any tree or plant, or tie or hitch any animal to any tree, plant or bush.
   C.   Climb any tree, or walk, stand or sit upon any monument, vase,
fountain, railing, fence or any other park property not designated or normally
used for such purposes.
   D.   Remove or cause to be removed any sod, earth, downed timber, rock, sand
or gravel, or remove or cause to be removed any other natural material from
park district property, unless necessitated by the performance of restorative
maintenance, or construction work, pursuant to contract with the district.
   E.   Hunt, trap, molest, wound, poison or kill, or attempt to hunt, trap,
molest, wound, poison, or kill any animal, bird or reptile, or disturb any
nest, lair, den or burrow of any animal, bird or reptile, without written
permission of the director.
   F.   Release or cause to be released any wild, or domestic animal, bird or
reptile, or distribute the seeds or spores of any flowering or nonflowering
plants into or upon park lands, without written permission of the director.
   G.   Ride, lead or allow to be loose upon park premises, any horse, pony or
other riding animal.
   H.   Use or cause to be used any chemical or biological pesticide or any
other substance, measured or process designated to alter the anatomy or
physiology of any organism for the purpose of directly manipulating their
populations, without written permission of the director and then only in
compliance with all applicable laws of the state of Illinois and the United
States Of America. (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-7: DOMESTIC DOGS AND CATS:
   A.   No person shall bring any bird or animal into the park system other
than domestic dogs and cats.
   B.   Persons owning or having right to immediate custody or control of any
dog or cat shall not permit any or all such dog or cat to enter into or remain
in the park system, unless at all times that it is within the park system, such
dog or cat is, by means of a leash or other physical equipment, entirely and
continuously under and subject to the direction and control of a person.
   C.   Any person who brings such dogs or cats into the park system shall pick
up and remove from the park system any and all solid waste of such dog or cat.
Disposal of any solid waste is prohibited in any park district waste
receptacle.
   D.   Seeing eye dogs or service animals for the visually impaired are
expressly excluded from this section and are authorized to be within the park
system. (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-8: VEHICLES:
   A.   No person shall drive or operate any motorized vehicle in the park
system, except upon designated parking areas. Persons not subject to this
provision are park district employees, police officers, and park district hired
contractors when acting under the authority of the director.
   B.   Operate a vehicle in disregard of any sign, signal, marking, or devise
erected, constructed or created by the village or any public body, or official
having jurisdiction for the purposes of regulating, warning, or guiding
traffic, or contrary to the order or direction of any police officer or other
person duly authorized to direct or regulate traffic.
   C.   Vehicle parking in any park system parking lot is permitted only during
park hours, as described in section
 8-13-3 of this chapter.
   D.   Park system parking lots are limited for participants of the park
system. Use of the park system parking lot for any other use except use of the
park system without written permission from the director is prohibited.
   E.   No person may operate a motorized vehicle in such a manner so as to
cause or produce unnecessary loud, raucous noise. Excessive or unusual noise,
including, but not limited to, the racing of the motor, the continuous sounding
of a horn or other signal device, audio music heard beyond twenty five feet of
the vehicle, the creation of tire friction by sudden, unnecessary motor
acceleration or rapid turning or weaving, or the failure to have a properly
operating muffler.
   F.   No person in charge of a motorized vehicle within the park system shall
permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine.
   G.   Operate any motor vehicle at a rate of speed or in any manner that is
unreasonable or imprudent, not having regard to the traffic and use of the way,
condition or the weather, visibility, condition or the roadway and other
surrounding conditions, so as to endanger the life, limb, or injure the
property of any persons. (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-9: BICYCLES, SKATEBOARDS, ROLLERBLADES:
No person shall, in connection with any property of the park district:
   A.   Ride a bicycle on any path, roadway, or other areas designated and
posted prohibiting bicycles, skateboards or rollerblades.
   B.   Operate a bicycle, skateboard, or rollerblade in a reckless manner so
as to endanger pedestrians or the rider or riders thereof.
   C.   Leave unattended any bicycle, except in those designated for such
purpose, and then only in such a manner as not to create a nuisance or hazard
to the public. (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-10: SPORTS AND GAMES:
No person shall, in connection with any property of the park district:
   A.   Golf In The Parks: Swing or make use of any golf club nor play golf,
nor hit or putt golf balls within or into the park system.
   B.   Engine Powered Models And Toys: Start, fly, or use any fuel powered or
rocket or jet type or electric powered model aircraft, boat, or rocketlike
powered toy or model.
   C.   Aviation: Bring, land, or cause to descend or alight within the park
system any airplane, flying machine, balloon, parachute, or other apparatus for
aviation, except with the written permission of the director.
   D.   Games: Take part in the playing of any games involving thrown or
otherwise propelled objects such as balls, stones, arrows, javelins, or model
airplanes. The use of lawn darts on any park property is specifically
prohibited.
   E.   Gambling: Manage, operate or engage in gambling of any form without
written permission of the director, and then only in compliance with all local,
state and federal law. (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-11: WINTER SPORTS:
No person shall, in connection with any property of the park district:
   A.   Inadequate Snow: Sled, toboggan, ski or slide on any area posted as
being "unsafe" or "hazardous" or as being "closed" due to inadequate snow
cover, or other environmental conditions, or upon being duly notified of such
by the director or authorized park district personnel.
   B.   Inadequate Ice: Ice skate on any area posted as being "unsafe" or
"hazardous" or as being closed due to inadequate ice or other environmental
conditions, or upon being duly notified of such by the director or authorized
park district personnel.
   C.   Tennis Courts: Access or use the platform tennis courts without
required membership, guest pass, as a registered participant to a platform
tennis program, or as a participant to a platform tennis lesson with approval
from the director.
   D.   Snowmobiles: Operate a snowmobile upon any park property. (Ord. 3510,
3-10-2014)
8-13-12: PERSONAL CONDUCT:
No person shall, in connection with any property of the park district:
   A.   Public Assemblies, Meetings: Hold any public meetings, exhibits,
contests, tournaments, concerts or public entertainment of any kind within the
park system without written approval from the director.
   B.   Obstruction Of Use: Exercise exclusive control or dominion over park
district property within the park system without written approval from the
director.
   C.   Weapons: Have in their possession or on or about their person or use
any firearm, pistol, revolver, shotgun, ammunition, bow and arrow, crossbow,
slingshot, blackjack, billy club, or device capable of discharging a projectile
by air, spirit, gas or explosive, any explosive substance or harmful solid,
liquid or gaseous substance, any tear gas or any disabling chemical agent or
any other dangerous weapon.
   D.   Fireworks: Have in their possession or on or about their person or use
any sparklers, fireworks, pyrotechnic devices or explosive devices at any time
within the park system without written approval from the director.
   E.   Alcohol And Controlled Substances: Be under the influence of alcohol,
illegal drugs or, other controlled substances shall enter, be or remain in the
park system, nor shall any person bring within, possess, sell, give away,
inhale, ingest or otherwise use or consume any alcohol, illegal drugs or
controlled substances in the park system. The smoking of cigarettes, cigars, or
pipe tobacco is prohibited inside or within twenty five feet of any building,
facility or structure, or within one hundred feet of any organized activity
within the park system.
   F.   Disorderly Conduct: Make countenance or assist in making any improper
noise, riot, disturbance, breach of the peace, or diversion tending to a breach
of peace, in the park system, or be guilty of any disorderly conduct therein,
or collect with other persons, in bodies or crowds for unlawful purposes, or
for any purpose to the annoyance or obstruction or disturbance of other
persons.
   G.   Improper Speech And Conduct: Use or engage in any abusive, threatening,
insulting, indecent, profane, or obscene language, signs, symbols, postures, or
acts or employ any such language or acts in such a way as to be conducive to a
breach of peace in the park system, as reasonably determined by any person
authorized to enforce this chapter. No person shall behave in any manner that
is unsportsmanlike, insulting, provoking, abusive, potentially harmful or
physically harmful toward any person while within the park system, as
reasonably determined by any person authorized to enforce this chapter.
   H.   Public Indecency: Engage in conduct that is publicly indecent, and a
person shall be deemed to have committed an act of public indecency when any
person performs any of the following acts:
      1.   An act of sexual intercourse.
      2.   An act of deviate sexual conduct.
      3.   A lewd exposure of the body, done with intent to arouse or satisfy
the sexual desire of the person.
      4.   A lewd fondling or caressing of the body on another person of either
sex.
   I.   Unlawful Use Of Photographic Or Video Equipment: The use of any device
with photographic or video capabilities is not permitted within restrooms
within the park system, or locker rooms, shower rooms, restrooms, or changing
rooms in other facilities where and when park district programs are being
conducted. (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-13: HINDERING OR BRIBING EMPLOYEES:
No person shall, in connection with any property of the park district:
   A.   Interfere with, unreasonably disrupt, delay, or in any manner hinder
performance of their duties.
   B.   Give or offer to give an employee any money, gift, privilege, or
article of value on or off park district property in order to violate the
provisions of this chapter or any other park district ordinance, contract,
permit, or statutes of the state of Illinois and the United States, or in order
to gain or receive special consideration in applying for any use or privilege,
or to gain special consideration and treatment in the use of any park district
property or facility. (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-14: ADVERTISING AND VENDING:
No person shall, in connection with any property of the park district:
   A.   Advertise: Post, affix, or otherwise display any place card, bill,
notice or advertisement of any kind in the park system, nor shall any person
distribute, cast, throw or place any handbill, pamphlet, circular,
advertisement or notice of any kind in the park system, nor shall any person
post, stencil or otherwise affix any notice, bill, advertisement or other
papers upon any structure or thing in or about the park system without written
approval from the director.
   B.   Concession Contract Agreement: Expose or offer for sale or hire any
articles or things, or conduct or solicit any business, trade or occupation or
profession without a concession contract agreement approved by the board of
commissioners, and then only in accordance with the terms and conditions
thereof, it being the intention of the park district to control commercial
enterprises or sales on park district lands.
   C.   Payment: Enter, without invitation or without having paid. (Ord. 3510,
3-10-2014)
8-13-15: FIRES:
No person shall, in connection with any property of the park district:
   A.   Set fire or cause to be set on fire, any tree, garden, grassland,
refuge container or structure.
   B.   Build a fire anywhere for any purpose, except in a park district fire
pit with written permission from the park district and the River Forest fire
department is required. (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
8-13-16: ADDITIONAL OR TEMPORARY RULES AND REGULATIONS:
No person shall violate any rule of the park district relating to the use and
administration of the park system. The board of commissioners or the director
or authorized representatives may issue such additional or temporary rules and
regulations as are necessary to incur public health and safety in the use and
enjoyment of any and all park facilities, including, but not limited to, its
park lands, other recreational activities, and any special events. No person
shall use any park district facility, which in the opinion of the director, is
not in condition for use, and all persons shall refrain from using the same
when requested by a written notice or personally requested by the board of
commissioners, the director, or authorized park district personnel. (Ord. 3510,
3-10-2014)
8-13-17: FINES:
   A.   Fine: Any person violating a clause or provision of any section of this
chapter shall be fined, upon conviction thereof, not less than fifty dollars
nor more than one thousand dollars for each convicted offense.
   B.   Eviction, Expulsion: Any person violating any clause or provision of
any section of this chapter may be evicted or expelled from the park district
by any person empowered to enforce this chapter as prescribed in section
8-13-2 of this chapter.
   C.   Damage; Restitution: Any person violating any clause or provision of
any section of this chapter and having caused damage to the building, property
or equipment of the park district, shall make restitution in addition to any
other fine or penalty imposed. Restitution shall include all expenses required
to make the park district whole, including, but not limited to, contractor's
fee, attorney fees and court costs. (Ord. 3510, 3-10-2014)
CHAPTER 14
BEES AND BEEKEEPING CONTROL
SECTION:
8-14-1: Definitions
8-14-2: Beekeeping Permit
8-14-3: Intent To Apply For Beekeeping Permit Notification
8-14-4: Colony Densities
8-14-5: Maintenance
8-14-6: Hive Location
8-14-7: Release And Indemnification
8-14-8: Violation And Penalty
8-14-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter the following terms, unless the context otherwise
requires, are defined as follows:
   APIARY: The assembly of one or more hives or colonies of honeybees at a
single location.
   APIARY INSPECTION: Inspection of an apiary and the surrounding area for
compliance with this chapter.
   BEEKEEPER: A person who owns or has charge of one or more colonies of
honeybees.
   BEEKEEPING: The act of owning or caring for one or more apiaries.
   BEEKEEPING EQUIPMENT: Anything used in the operation of an apiary, such as
hive bodies, supers, frames, top and bottom boards and extractors.
   COLONY: The entire honeybee family or social unit living together.
   FAMILY MEMBER: One or more persons occupying and residing in a dwelling on a
lot and living as a single housekeeping unit.
   HIVE: A frame or structure used or employed as a domicile for bees.
   HONEYBEE: The common domestic honeybee, limited to the Apis mellifera
species, specifically excluding the African honeybee, Apis mellifera scutellata
or "Africanized honeybees".
   LOT: A contiguous parcel of land under common ownership.
   NUCLEUS OR NUC COLONIES: Small honeybee colonies created from larger
colonies. The term refers both to the smaller size box and the colony of
honeybees within it.
   PERSON: Any natural person or education institution. (Ord. 3666, 11-27-2017)
8-14-2: BEEKEEPING PERMIT:
   A.   Permit Required: Beekeeping is prohibited unless a permit has first
been obtained from the Village in accordance with the terms of this chapter.
Unpermitted beekeeping is declared a nuisance. Persons desiring to establish
and maintain a honeybee apiary in the Village shall first obtain a permit from
the Village.
Beekeepers who owned or operated a honeybee apiary within the Village prior to
November 27, 2017, and who wish to continue to do so after November 27, 2017,
shall apply for a Village beekeeping permit.
At the time of application for a Village beekeeping permit, the applicant shall
provide the Village with:
      1.   Proof of compliance with the requirements of this chapter, including
the property bee notification requirement in section
8-14-3 of this chapter, including a copy of the notice and mailing list;
      2.   Proof that the applicant is at least eighteen years of age;
      3.   A description of the number of colonies requested to be kept on the
lot;
      4.   A depiction of the lot on which the colony, or colonies, are
proposed to be located and a depiction of the location on the lot on which the
colony, or colonies, are proposed to be located;
      5.   A twenty five dollar nonrefundable permit application fee; and
      6.   Such other information or documents as the Village may request.
When complete, the Village shall review the permit application and determine
whether the permit should be issued. If the Village determines the permit
should be issued, the Village shall issue the permit to the applicant. The
Village may attach conditions of approval on a permit issued under this
chapter. The Village may deny, suspend or revoke any permit issued under this
chapter in accordance with the procedures set forth in section
3-1-11 of this Code, substituting "license" for "permit" and "business" for
"beekeeping" therein, and any person aggrieved by such denial, suspension or
revocation may appeal it in accordance with the procedures set forth in section
3-1-12 of this Code, substituting "license" for "permit" and "business" for
"beekeeping" therein. A permit may be suspended or revoked for the reasons set
forth in subsection
3-1-11C of this Code, or if the Village determines that beekeeping cannot be
conducted on the lot in a safe manner.
   B.   Permit Expiration And Renewal: Permits shall expire on November 30 of
each calendar year. Permit holders must apply to renew their permit annually by
completing a renewal application, by paying a twenty five dollar nonrefundable
permit renewal fee, and by giving the notice required in section
8-14-3 of this chapter to new adjacent property owners, if any, since the date
the last permit was issued. The notice requirements herein shall not apply to
Dominican University.
   C.   Apiary Inspection Right Of Entry: By applying for a permit, the
applicant authorizes the Village and its employees and agents to enter onto the
lot that contains the apiary for the purpose of inspecting the lot and the
apiary for compliance with this chapter, both prior to the issuance of a
permit, and, if a permit is issued, for the duration of the permit or so long
as an apiary is present on the lot.
   D.   Nontransferability: No permit shall be assigned or transferred to any
other person or entity. No refund shall be granted for any unexpired period of
a permit if the permit is turned in, surrendered, suspended or revoked. If a
permittee moves to a new lot within the Village, a permit may be transferred to
the new lot, so long as all requirements of this chapter are satisfied and
confirmed by the Village prior to establishment of the colony or colonies on
the new lot, and so long as the notification requirements of section
8-14-3 of this chapter are satisfied and confirmed by the Village prior to
establishment of the colony or colonies on the new lot.
   E.   State Registration: All permittees shall register the apiary on the lot
with the State of Illinois Department of Agriculture and maintain their
apiaries in accordance with the Illinois Bees and Apiaries Act, 510 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 20/1, et seq., and other applicable State, Federal and
Village laws, ordinances, rules, regulations and directives. (Ord. 3666, 11-27-
2017)
8-14-3: INTENT TO APPLY FOR BEEKEEPING PERMIT NOTIFICATION:
Prior to applying for an initial permit, the applicant must provide written
proof that the applicant served written notice, by first class U.S. mail, no
more than thirty calendar days and no less than fifteen calendar days prior to
the submission of the permit application, to all properties adjacent to the
applicant's lot, of the applicant's intent to apply for a permit. The written
notice shall inform the recipients of the proposed application for a permit,
and the ability of the recipients to object to the application on the grounds
set forth below. The form of the written notice shall be available from the
Village. The notice requirements herein shall not apply to Dominican
University.
Within seven calendar days of receiving notice from the applicant, a recipient
may file a written objection with the Village to the applicant's permit
application if any recipient, a recipient's family member or a recipient's
employee (if the recipient is a business) suffers from anaphylaxis or a related
life-threatening condition. If the objector provides documentation from a
licensed physician or medical professional that confirms an anaphylaxis
reaction or a life-threatening condition related to bee stings, the application
shall be denied. (Ord. 3666, 11-27-2017)
8-14-4: COLONY DENSITIES:
   A.   Colony Limits: No more than two colonies shall be located on a lot,
with the exception of Dominican University, as set forth in subsection B of
this section.
   B.   Dominican University Exception: Notwithstanding the limitations to bee
colony densities herein, Dominican University may continue to keep up to four
colonies on its lot, so long as the colonies continue to be an integral part of
Dominican University's educational program, so long as Dominican University
adheres to all other requirements of this chapter.
   C.   Limits On Permits: A maximum of twenty two permits may be issued by the
Village at a time, with renewal applications taking priority over new
applications. All new applications shall be considered on a first come first
served basis. In the event of an excess of twenty two permits being requested,
the remaining applications will be placed on a first come first served waiting
list. (Ord. 3666, 11-27-2017)
8-14-5: MAINTENANCE:
   A.   Apiary Maintenance: All beekeeping equipment shall be kept in good
condition and unused equipment must be secured from weather, potential theft or
vandalism. No bee comb, wax or other materials shall be left upon the grounds
of the apiary, which might encourage disturbance or robbing by wildlife or
domestic animals. Beekeepers shall promptly store or dispose of any bee comb,
wax or other materials which have been removed from the hive in a sealed
container or within a building or other bee proof enclosure.
   B.   Type Of Hives: All colonies must be kept in "inspect accessible" type
hives with removable frames or comb, which must be kept in sound and usable
condition.
   C.   Water: A convenient and adequate source of water must be available on
the lot at all times as long as the colonies remain active outside the hive.
The purpose of this requirement is to prevent bees from congregating at
swimming pools, faucets, pet water bowls, birdbaths or other water sources
where they may cause human, bird, or domestic pet contact. The water shall be
maintained so as not to become stagnant.
   D.   Record Keeping: Beekeepers shall maintain records of colony maintenance
and monitoring of hive health. These records are to be made available to the
Village upon request.
   E.   Limits On Nucleus Or Nuc Colonies: Beekeepers may create and maintain
up to two nucleus or nuc colonies for purposes of managing their beehive
population and queen bee health. (Ord. 3666, 11-27-2017)
8-14-6: HIVE LOCATION:
   A.   Distance From Property Lines: Hives shall be kept a minimum of five
feet from all of the lot's property lines, and oriented so that flight patterns
face away from the closest lot fence line on the lot.
   B.   Flyways: A hive shall be placed on a lot so that the general flight
pattern of the bees is in a direction and distance that will deter bee contact
with humans and domesticated animals. If this cannot be achieved due to lot
constraints, the beekeeper shall install a fly-wall at least two feet higher
than the hive entrance, and no more than five feet from said entrance. The fly-
wall shall be made of vegetation or fencing material.
   C.   Fencing: If the lot where a hive is located is not completely fenced
in, the beekeeper shall erect a fence and/or barrier around the hives
themselves that will be at least four feet high and no closer than five feet
from the hive. The requirements of this subsection C shall not apply to a hive
on a rooftop.
   D.   Signage: A weatherproof sign at least ten inches by ten inches shall be
installed at either the entrance(s) of the yard or the entrance to the fence
erected around a hive in a non-fenced in yard. The sign shall read "State
Registered Beehive(s) on Property" or similar language that makes it clear that
bees are on the premises. The Village-issued permit number must be included and
displayed clearly. (Ord. 3666, 11-27-2017)
8-14-7: RELEASE AND INDEMNIFICATION:
By accepting a permit under this chapter, a permittee shall have agreed to:
   A.   Waive and relinquish any and all claims, demands or causes of action of
any kind, including but not limited to personal injuries, illness or death,
damages, or economic and non-economic damages or losses, that the permittee or
its officers (if any), officials (if any), employees (if any), contractors,
subcontractors, volunteers, agents (if any), invitees, guests and members of
the public ("permittee affiliates") may have against the Village and its
officers, appointed and elected officials, President and Trustees, employees,
agents, attorneys and volunteers ("Village affiliates") arising out of,
connected with or in any way associated with beekeeping and the activities
allowed under the permit.
   B.   Protect, indemnify, save and hold forever harmless and defend the
Village affiliates from and against any and all liabilities, obligations,
claims, injuries, illness, death, damages or losses of any kind, penalties,
causes of action, costs and expenses brought by any person, including any
permittee affiliates, arising out of, connected with or in any way associated
with beekeeping and the activities allowed under the permit.
The obligations in this section shall be, and are, incorporated into each
permit granted under this chapter, and are an integral part thereof. (Ord.
3666, 11-27-2017)
8-14-8: VIOLATION AND PENALTY:
No bees may be kept in the Village except as permitted in this chapter. Anyone
violating any provision of this chapter may be fined up to five hundred
dollars, with each day the violation exists constituting a separate violation.
(Ord. 3666, 11-27-2017)
TITLE 9
TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
VEHICLE LICENSES
SECTION:
9-1-1: License Required
9-1-2: Application For License
9-1-3: Fees
9-1-4: License Emblems
9-1-5: Penalty
9-1-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
The owner of any motor vehicle registered to a village address or any resident
who applies for a village parking permit pursuant to section
9-2-20 or
9-2-24 of this title shall be required to obtain and display a village license.
This licensing requirement shall apply to the owner of any motor vehicles
temporarily not in operating condition or intermittently garaged outside of the
village. (Ord. 3398, 11-14-2011)
9-1-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person requiring a license for any such motor vehicle shall prepare an
application upon a form provided by the village, setting forth the name and
address of the applicant, a description of the motor vehicle, its state license
number, if any, and such other information as may be prescribed. Upon payment
by the applicant of the license fee provided in section
9-1-3 of this chapter, the village shall issue the license. (Ord. 2844, 9-21-
1999)
9-1-3: FEES:
The license fees to be paid annually to the village shall be as follows:
Passenger automobiles and school buses                                $45.00
Motorcycles, scooters and mopeds                                      25.00
Vehicles with state of Illinois issued antique license plates         25.00
Recreational vehicles (RVs)                                           50.00
Truck with maximum load not to exceed 5 tons                          50.00
Truck with maximum load in excess of 5 tons                           70.00
Senior citizen rate (residents 65 years or older with proof of age) 1 25.00
automobile per family or household only
Duplicate tags (with return of a portion of old sticker)              2.00
Active duty military or veteran designation                           25.00
 
The above license fees shall be due and payable before July 15 in each year and
all licenses shall expire on July 14 of the following year. The owner of any
vehicle required to have a license who fails to pay the prescribed fee before
July 15 shall be required to pay the additional sum of ten dollars if the
license fee is paid before August 14. If the owner pays the prescribed fee on
or after August 15 but before October 15, he shall be required to pay the
additional sum of fifteen dollars. If the owner pays the prescribed fee on or
after October 15, he shall be required to pay the additional sum of twenty
dollars. The owner or operator of any vehicle coming into possession thereof
after July 15 shall not be subject to any penalty if the license fee is paid
within thirty days of obtaining possession of said vehicle or of moving into
the village. If such possession is not acquired until after January 15, only
one-half the annual fee shall be required for the balance of the license year.
(Ord. 3457, 10-8-2012; amd. Ord. 3912, 11-13-2023)
9-1-4: LICENSE EMBLEMS:
Upon issuance of the license, the village clerk shall deliver to the applicant
a sticker bearing a number identical with the number of such license, together
with the words "River Forest" and the year for which said license is issued. It
shall be the duty of the licensee to affix the same in the lower right hand
corner of the glass part of the windshield of such vehicle. Motorcycles,
scooters and mopeds will be issued a plate of plastic or other material bearing
a number identical with the number of such license, together with the words
"River Forest" and the year for which said license is issued, which shall be
attached to the state license plate of the vehicle. (Ord. 2844, 9-21-1999)
9-1-5: PENALTY:
Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter
shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars for each offense. Each day in which a violation occurs or
continues shall constitute a separate offense. A person charged with violating
a provision of this chapter may be issued a violation notice in lieu of the
village filing a complaint in court against that person. The violation notice
shall be administratively adjudicated pursuant to chapter 6 of this title.
(Ord. 3398, 11-14-2011)
CHAPTER 2
TRAFFIC REGULATIONS
SECTION:

9-2-28: Business Parking Permit Zones
9-2-29: Parking Reserve Funds
9-2-30: Overweight Vehicles
9-2-1: STATE MOTOR VEHICLE LAWS ADOPTED:
There is hereby adopted for the purpose of prescribing regulations for
pedestrians and the operation of vehicles on the village streets, that certain
code known as the Illinois vehicle code, being in particular 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes, three copies of which code have been and now are filed in
the office of the village clerk, and the same is hereby adopted and represented
as fully as if set out at length herein, and the provisions thereof shall be
controlling within the limits of the village. (1981 Code)
9-2-2: U-TURNS:
It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to make U-turns on the
streets designated in schedule 10, section
 9-3-10 of this title. (1981 Code)
9-2-3: THROUGH STREETS:
The streets and parts of streets designated in schedule 1, section
9-3-1 of this title are hereby declared to constitute through streets. It shall
be unlawful to drive any vehicle into a through street without first bringing
such vehicle to a full stop within ten feet of the street line, except where
traffic is regulated by traffic lights. (1981 Code)
9-2-4: STOP INTERSECTIONS:
It shall be unlawful to drive any vehicle into the intersections of the streets
set out in schedule 2, section
9-3-2 of this title, without first bringing such vehicle to a full stop at said
intersections. (1981 Code)
9-2-5: ONE-WAY STREETS AND ALLEYS:
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle on any of the streets or alleys
designated as one-way in schedule 3, section
9-3-3 of this title, in any direction other than that so indicated. (1981 Code)
9-2-6: TRUCK AND BUS ROUTES:
It shall be unlawful to drive any truck or bus on any streets named in schedule
6, section
9-3-6 of this title or in any alley. Vehicles may, however, use said streets
for the sole purpose of crossing said streets at intersections and of making
deliveries and pick ups on said streets. Vehicles may also use said alleys for
the sole purpose of making deliveries and pick ups on said alleys, provided
that the loading facility is not accessible via a street. Operators of
emergency vehicles and of government owned vehicles are exempt from the
provisions of this section. (Ord. 2397, 7-23-1990)
9-2-7: LIMITED LOAD STREETS:
It shall be unlawful to operate any vehicle which, with its load, exceeds ten
thousand pounds in weight on any of the streets designated in schedule 6,
section of this title, and on any streets so designated by ordinance of the
president and board. (1981 Code; amd. Ord. 3934, 8-12-2024)
9-2-8: PARKING VEHICLES FOR SALE:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of
displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any business street from
which vehicle merchandise is peddled. (1981 Code)
9-2-9: ALL NIGHT PARKING:
No person shall park a vehicle on any street for a period of time longer than
thirty minutes between the hours of two o'clock A.M. and six o'clock A.M. of
any day, except physicians on emergency calls. (Ord. 3099, 2-14-2005)
9-2-10: PARKING IN LOADING ZONES:
It shall be unlawful for the driver of a vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle
for a period of time longer than is necessary for the loading and unloading of
passengers, or to exceed three minutes, and for the driver to stand any freight
carrying vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary to load, unload
and deliver materials, not to exceed thirty minutes, in any place designated by
the village board as a loading zone and marked as such, or at any place not to
exceed seventy five feet along the curb before the entrance to a public
building. For designated loading zones, see schedule 15, section
 9-3-15 of this title. (Ord. 2407, 11-26-1990)
9-2-11: PARKING IN BUS STOPS:
Subject to the concurrence of the traffic and safety commission 1  and to the
approval by ordinance of the president and board, the chief of police is hereby
authorized and required to establish bus stops on such public streets in such
places and in such number and of such length as he shall determine to be of the
greatest benefit and convenience to the public, and every such bus stop shall
be designated by appropriate signs. For specific bus stop designations, see
schedule 5, section
9-3-5 of this title.
   A.   The driver of a bus shall:
      1.   Not stop such vehicle upon any street at any place other than at a
designated bus stop. The term "bus stop" is defined as a fixed area in the
roadway parallel and adjacent to the curb set aside for the expeditious loading
and unloading of passengers only.
      2.   Not stop such vehicle upon any street at any place for the purpose
of loading or unloading passengers other than at a designated bus stop, except
in case of emergency.
      3.   Enter a bus stop zone on a public street in such a manner that the
bus, when stopped to load or unload passengers, shall be in a position with the
right front wheel of such bus not farther than eighteen inches from the curb
and the bus approximately parallel to the curb so as to not unduly impede the
movement of other vehicular traffic.
   B.   No vehicle other than a bus shall be parked in a place so designated as
a bus stop. (1981 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 5 of this code.
9-2-12: TIME LIMIT PARKING:
Except on Sundays or holidays, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle for a
longer consecutive period of time than the time permitted by the police
department, by ordinance or by signs so posted. For specific time limit
parking, see section
9-3-13, "Schedule 13, Time Limit Parking", of this title. (1981 Code)
9-2-13: SIGNS POSTED:
   A.   Authority To Post Signs: The chief of police shall cause signs to be
posted in all areas where traffic control is regulated, parking is limited, or
parking is prohibited by the village board, indicating such limitation or
prohibitions thereon.
   B.   Adoption Of MUTCD: All traffic control devices installed within the
public right of way shall follow the standards set forth in the most current
edition of the "Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices For Streets And
Highways" (MUTCD). Any proposed variance from these standards shall be subject
to the approval of the village engineer. (Ord. 3608, 8-8-2016)
9-2-14: STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING TO OBSTRUCT TRAFFIC:
No vehicle shall be operated or allowed to remain upon any street in such a
manner as to form an unreasonable obstruction to the traffic thereon. (1981
Code)
9-2-15: PARKING DURING SNOWFALL:
It is unlawful to park any vehicle on any street or alley at any time after the
snow on the street or alley exceeds two inches in depth and for an eight hour
period following the cessation of the snowfall. (Ord. 3145, 1-9-2006)
9-2-16: TRAFFIC OFFENSES:
   A.   Clinging To Vehicles: It shall be unlawful for any person on any street
riding a bicycle, motorcycle or any toy vehicle or as a pedestrian, to cling to
or attach himself or his vehicle to any moving motor vehicle or wagon.
   B.   Toy Vehicles: It shall be unlawful for any person upon skates, a
skateboard, a coaster, sled or other toy vehicle to go upon any roadway other
than at a crosswalk.
   C.   Riding On Running Boards: It shall be unlawful for any person to ride
upon the fenders, running board or outside step of any vehicle or upon any part
of any vehicle other than the seats installed by the manufacturer.
   D.   Bicycles, Mopeds And Motorcycles: It shall be unlawful for more than
one person to ride upon any bicycle, moped or motorcycle other than upon a seat
attached to said vehicle.
   E.   Spilling Loads: It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to be so loaded
that any part of its load spills or drops on any street or alley in the
village.
   F.   Negligent Driving: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any
vehicle upon a public way negligently, needlessly, and without due caution in a
manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any persons or property.
(1981 Code)
   G.   Driving Of Certain Motorized Vehicles Prohibited: No person shall use,
operate, or be in control of any all-terrain vehicle, go-kart, minibike,
motorized skateboard or scooter, or off road motorcycle, not capable of being
licensed under the Illinois vehicle code, on any public street or on any
private property without the express consent of the owner.
The provisions of this section shall not apply to any of the above referenced
devices when participating in a parade authorized by the village, or when
operated by a law enforcement officer in the performance of official duties.
(Ord. 3016, 4-14-2003)
9-2-17: ACCESSIBLE PARKING:
It shall be unlawful to park a motor vehicle in any parking place reserved for
persons with a disability or disabled veterans by any person using a motor
vehicle not bearing registration plates specified in 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-1301.1 or not displaying a special decal for accessible parking
specified in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1301.2.
   A.   Any motor vehicle bearing person with a disability registration plates
or a special decal for accessible parking as evidence that the vehicle is
operated by or for a person with a disability or disabled veteran may park, in
addition to any lawful place, in any parking space specifically reserved, by
posting of an official sign, for such vehicles. The official sign shall be
mounted on a post at a level and a location where it is clearly visible by the
driver of any motor vehicle approaching the parking place reserved for
accessible parking.
   B.   A special decal for accessible parking shall be the property of such
person with a disability and may be used by that person to designate and
identify a vehicle not owned or displaying a registration plate to designate
when the vehicle is being used to transport said person with a disability, and
thus is entitled to enjoy all the privileges that would be afforded a disabled
vehicle licensed for a person with disabilities. (1981 Code; amd. Ord. 3139,
12-12-2005)
      1.   The River Forest Township authorities shall be responsible for the
provision of such decal, its issuance and designated placement within the
vehicle. The cost of such decal shall be at the discretion of the township
authorities. (1981 Code)
      2.   The chief of police shall maintain an up to date listing of all
persons who have been issued a special decal for accessible parking. (1981
Code; amd. Ord. 3139, 12-12-2005)
   C.   Parking privileges granted by this section are strictly limited to the
person to whom the special registration plates or decals were issued and to
qualified operators acting under his express direction while the disabled
person is present. (1981 Code)
   D.   For designated accessible parking zones, see section
9-3-20, "Schedule 20, Accessible Parking Zones Designated", of this title.
(Ord. 2415, 1-28-1991; amd. Ord. 3139, 12-12-2005)
9-2-18: EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   The provisions of this title regulating the movement or parking of
vehicles shall not apply to emergency vehicles while the driver thereof is
engaged in the performance of emergency duties. Nor shall such provisions apply
to persons engaged in repairing or otherwise improving the streets under the
authority of the board or of the state. (Ord. 3099, 2-14-2005)
   B.   The police department upon the request of a resident shall be
authorized to waive parking restrictions except for the following: loading
zones, bus stops, parking during snow removal, accessible parking, village
parking lots, permit parking zones, daily parking zones, and business parking
permit zones. (Ord. 3099, 2-14-2005; amd. Ord. 3139, 12-12-2005)
9-2-19: PENALTY:
   A.   Alternate Penalties; Compliance Warning Tickets: Effective September 9,
2024, any person, pursuant to the issuance of a compliance warning ticket, who
is accused of a violation of certain sections of this code as hereinafter
described in subsection B of this section, except a traffic offense for which a
court appearance is required pursuant to chapter 110A Illinois Compiled
Statutes, 1992, may settle and compromise that ticket by paying to the village
a fine as listed in the Fine Payment Schedule of section 
9-6-9 of this title.
   The issuance of compliance warning citations shall be as a courtesy in lieu
of instituting prosecution in court for the alleged offense. If the person
accused of the violation does not settle the claim, a uniform traffic complaint
or notice to appear will be issued for that violation and otherwise that person
shall be subject to the general penalties set forth in the Illinois vehicle
code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes. (Ord. 3487, 6-24-2013)
   B.   Compliance Violations: The following violations of the Illinois vehicle
code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes, as adopted by the village in section
9-2-1 of this chapter shall be subject to the procedures described in
subsection A of this section: (Ord. 2505, 7-27-1992)
      5/3-112(b) (failure to transfer title within five days)
      5/3-401(a) (no valid registration - never applied)
      5/3-404 (no bill of lading or manifest/dispatch record)
      5/3-411 (failure to carry registration card or reciprocity permit -
second division vehicle)
      5/3-413(a,b) (improper display of license plates)
      5/3-413(f) (operation of vehicle with expired registration plate or
sticker)
      5/3-416 (failure to notify the secretary of state of name/address change)
      5/3-417(a) (failure to immediately apply for replacement registration
card, plate or sticker)
      5/3-701(1) (no valid registration - no valid plate or sticker obtained)
      5/3-701(2) (no valid registration - reciprocity, prorate or
apportionment)
      5/5-201(h) (no in-transit plates)
      5/5-202(e) (failure to display three tow truck plates)
      5/6-107(e) (graduated driver's license holder under age 18, more than one
front seat passenger, and/or more rear seat passengers than safety belts
available)
      5/6-107(f) (graduated driver's license holder under age 18, any
passengers under age 19 not wearing safety belts)
      5/6-107(g) (graduated driver's license holder under age 18, more than one
passenger under age 20)
      5/6-112 (failure to carry or produce driver's license)
      5/6-116 (failure to notify secretary of state of driver's license address
change within 10 days, or a name change within 30 days)
      5/11-1401 (leaving running motor vehicle unattended)
      5/11-1404(a) (failure to wear eye protection, driver or passenger,
motorcycle, motor driven cycle, or motorized pedalcycle)
      5/11-1406 (obstruction of driver's view or driving mechanism)
      5/11-1407 (opening and closing vehicle doors)
      5/11-1410 (coasting prohibited)
      5/11-1411 (following fire apparatus prohibited)
      5/11-1413(a) (depositing material or litter upon public highway)
      5/11-1419.01 (failure to display Illinois motor fuel tax identification
card)
      5/11-1419.01 (failure to display external Illinois motor fuel tax
identification device)
      5/11-1507(a) (operation of bicycle without lamp reflector)
      5/12-101(a) (operation of vehicle with unsafe equipment)
      5/12-201(a) (operation of motorcycle without at least one lighted lamp)
      5/12-201(b) (driving vehicles without two lighted headlamps and tail

9-2-20: VILLAGE PARKING LOTS:
   A.   Village Parking Lots Established: For the purpose of this section, the
words "Village parking lots" are hereby defined to mean the parking area north
of Park District headquarters at 401 Thatcher Avenue and south of the apartment
building at 411 - 419 Thatcher Avenue (known as the Thatcher Avenue east
parking lot); the parking area at the northwest corner of Thatcher Avenue and
Central Avenue (known as the Thatcher Avenue west parking lot); the parking
area at the southeast corner of Park Avenue and Lake Street (known as the park
and lake lot); the twenty five designated spaces at the CVS Pharmacy lot at
7929 W. North Avenue (known as the CVS lot); and the parking lot adjacent to
the Village Hall at 400 Park Avenue including the on street parking spaces
(diagonal and parallel spaces) along Central Avenue between Park Avenue and the
Village Hall driveway (known as the Village Hall lots); and the parking area at
418 Franklin Avenue known as the 418 Franklin lot).
   B.   Permit Or Daily Fee Required: The owner of any motor vehicle shall be
required to obtain and display the applicable current Village parking permit or
pay the daily fee in accordance with the fee schedule in subsection D of this
section.
   C.   Application For Permit: Any person requiring a parking permit for a
motor vehicle shall prepare an application upon a form provided by the Village
Administrator setting forth the name and address of the applicant and such
other information as may be prescribed. Upon payment of the applicable permit
fee, the Village Administrator shall issue the permit. (Ord. 2749, 12-8-1997)
   D.   Fees: The permit and daily fees for all Village parking lots shall be
as follows:

   E.   Advance Permit Purchase: Permits may be purchased for one to twelve
months in advance. Unused permits are not refundable. (Ord. 3326, 4-26-2010,
eff. 4-26-2010)
   F.   Restrictions:
      1.   No trucks shall be eligible to purchase an overnight parking permit.
      2.   No recreational vehicles shall be permitted.
      3.   Only vehicles displaying a current River Forest vehicle license and
a valid parking permit as described in this section shall be allowed to use the
Thatcher Avenue east lot, the park and lake lot, the twenty five designated
spaces in the CVS lot; and the eight designated spaces in the 418 Franklin lot.
      4.   Only overnight parking permit holders who can provide evidence of a
current monthly Metra commuter pass shall be eligible to make application for a
daytime parking permit in the Thatcher east lot.
      5.   Only vehicles in operable condition may be parked in a Village
parking lot.
      6.   No motor vehicle shall be parked in a Village parking lot between
two o'clock A.M. and six o'clock A.M. of any day, except as expressly permitted
by the Police Department or unless the motor vehicle has an overnight parking
permit.
      7.   Parking in a Village parking lot shall be only in spaces striped for
parking and it shall be unlawful to park in any area of a lot which is not
striped for parking or which has signs prohibiting parking, or to park a
vehicle in such a manner that incorporates the use of more than one designated
parking stall. The use of "Village Hall lots" shall be limited to Village of
River Forest employees and/or other authorized lot users.
      8.   Twenty spaces in the 418 Franklin lot shall be restricted to three
hour parking.
      9.   The use of a Village-owned electric vehicle charging station and
adjacent electric vehicle parking spaces shall be limited to electric vehicles
connected to an electric vehicle charging station. There shall be no fee or
charge for the first two hours of charging after connecting to a Village-owned
electric vehicle charging station. After the two-hour period, the usage fee for
electric vehicle charging shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per sixty-minute
interval, with a maximum fee of thirty dollars ($30.00).
   G.   Exemptions: Village officials and employees, while on duty, may park in
a Village parking lot without payment of fee, provided they display a parking
permit exemption decal on the rear window. (Ord. 2749, 12-8-1997; amd. Ord.
2818, 3-22-1999, eff. 5-1-1999; Ord. 2928, 6-11-2001; Ord. 2989, 11-11-2002;
Ord. 3326, 4-26-2019, eff. 4-26-2010; Ord. 3701, 6-11-2018, eff. 7-1- 2018;
Ord. 3786, 11-12-2019; Ord. 3921, 2-26-2024)
9-2-21: ALLEY PARKING:
It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle within an alley in such a manner or
under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of
the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall
stop, stand or park a vehicle in an alley in such a position as to block the
driveway entrance to any abutting property. (Ord. 2369, 12-11-1989)
9-2-22: PARKING IN STUDENT LOADING ZONES:
It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to park a vehicle, whether
occupied or not, for a period of time longer than is necessary for the loading
or unloading of passengers in any place designated as a student loading zone
and marked as such. For designated student loading zones, see section
9-3-16 of this title. (Ord. 2414, 1-28-1991)
9-2-23: RESIDENT PARKING ZONES:
   A.   Resident Parking Zones Established: Resident parking zones are hereby
established upon those streets or portions of streets for such days and times
as authorized by section
9-3-21 of this title.
   B.   Permit Required: Upon request, individual "one day visitor" parking
permits shall be issued to residents within a resident parking zone for use by
their nonresident visitors and guests. These permits shall be good for only one
day and shall expire at two o'clock A.M. on the day following the date printed
on the permit. These permits must be placed in a visible location on the
dashboard of the vehicle and must be validated by printing the date and address
of the resident host legibly on its face in the space provided for this
purpose.
   C.   Permit Fee: One "1-day visitor" parking permit shall be issued free of
charge upon request to any resident within a resident parking zone. This permit
form may be reproduced by the resident.
   D.   Regulations For Use: It shall be unlawful and a violation of this
section to park any vehicle in a resident parking zone unless the vehicle: 1)
is registered to a Village resident and displays a current Village license or
2) displays a valid "one day visitor" permit in accordance with the applicable
provisions of this section. (Ord. 3090, 12-13-2004)
9-2-24: PERMIT PARKING ZONES:
   A.   Permit Parking Zones Established: Permit parking zones are hereby
established upon those streets or portions of streets and such other designated
areas for such days and times as authorized by section
9-3-22 of this title.
   B.   Permit Required: The owner of any motor vehicle shall be required to
obtain and display a current Village parking permit by hanging it from the
rearview mirror before parking in any designated permit parking zone.
   C.   Application For Permit: Any person requiring a parking permit for a
motor vehicle shall prepare an application upon a form provided by the Village
Administrator, setting forth the name, address, telephone number and other
applicable information as may be prescribed. Upon payment of the monthly permit
fee, the Village Administrator shall issue the permit.
   D.   Permit Fees: The permit fees to be paid on a monthly basis are forty
five dollars per month for residents. The fee shall increase to fifty dollars
on May 1, 2019 and fifty five dollars on May 1, 2020. The permit fee for
motorcycle/scooter parking shall be twenty five dollars on May 1, 2019 and
twenty seven dollars and fifty cents on May 1, 2020. All permit fees shall be
required during the days and times described for each location included in
section
9-3-22  and 9-3-26 of this title.
   E.   Advance Purchase: Permits may be purchased from one to twelve months in
advance except that permit fees for Special Permit Parking Zone A is an annual
fee payable in advance. Unused permits are not refundable.
   F.   Regulations For Use: It shall be unlawful and a violation of this
section to park any vehicle in a permit parking zone unless the vehicle: 1)
displays a current River Forest vehicle license, 2) displays a valid parking
permit as described in this section, and 3) is parked so that the vehicle does
not occupy more than one designated parking stall. Except that vehicles using
the Special Permit Parking Zone A (south side of Central between Clinton Place
and Harlem) do not have to comply with item 1 of this subsection. (Ord. 2903,
11-27-2000; amd. Ord. 2749, 12- 8-1997; Ord. 3701, 6-11-2018, eff. 7-1-2018;
Ord. 3780, 9-23-2019)
9-2-25: DAILY PARKING ZONES:
   A.   Daily Parking Zones Established: Daily parking zones are hereby
established upon those streets, or portions of streets and such other
designated areas for such days and times as authorized by section
9-3-23  of this title.
   B.   Daily Parking Fee: The fee for use of the daily parking zone shall be
five dollars per day and shall be required during the days and times described
for each respective location included in section
9-3-23  of this title.
   C.   Daily Parking Fee - Motorcycles and Scooters: The fee for use of the
daily parking zone designated for motorcycles and scooters shall be two dollars
and fifty cents per day and shall be required during the days and times
described for each respective location included in section
9-3-26  of this title.
   D.   Regulations For Use: It shall be unlawful and a violation of this
section for any person to park a vehicle in a daily parking zone without
depositing the appropriate fee as described in subsection B of this section
through electronic means in accordance with the posted instructions or to park
a vehicle in such a manner that incorporates the use of more than one
designated parking stall. (Ord. 3515, 4-15-2014, eff. 5-1-2014; amd. Ord. 2437,
7-8-1991; Ord. 3701, 6-11-2018, eff. 7-1-2018; Ord. 3780, 9-23-2019)
9-2-26: IMMOBILIZATION OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
(Rep. by Ord. 3202, 6-11-2007)
9-2-27: RESIDENT PARKING PERMIT ZONES:
   A.   Resident Parking Permit Zone Established: Resident parking permit zones
are hereby established upon those streets or portions of streets for such days
and times as authorized by section
9-3-24 of this title.
   B.   Permit Required: The owner of any motor vehicle registered to an
address within a resident parking permit zone or to the guest or an employee of
a resident living within the zone shall be required to obtain and display a
current resident parking permit zone permit by hanging it from the rearview
mirror while parking in a designated resident parking permit zone.
   C.   Permit Fee: The Village shall issue one resident parking permit zone
permit to each vehicle registered with the Village within the resident parking
permit zone designated in section
9-3-24 of this title, up to a maximum of two permits per household at no
charge. A fee of one dollar will be charged for any additional resident parking
permit zone permit issued.
   D.   Regulations For Use: It shall be unlawful and a violation of this
section to park any vehicle in a resident parking permit zone unless the
vehicle: 1) displays a valid resident parking permit zone permit as described
in this section, and 2) is parked in accordance with all other applicable
Village parking regulations. (Ord. 2885, 6-26-2000, eff. 6-27-2000)
9-2-28: BUSINESS PARKING PERMIT ZONES:
   A.   Business Parking Permit Zone Established: Business parking permit zones
including Special Permit Parking Zone A are hereby established upon those
streets or portions of streets for such days and times as authorized by section
9-3-25 of this title.
   B.   Permit Required: The owner of any motor vehicle shall be required to
obtain and display a current business parking permit by hanging it from the
rearview mirror before parking in any designated business parking permit zone.
   C.   Application For Permit: Any business or individual requiring a business
parking permit for a motor vehicle shall prepare an application upon a form
provided by the Village Administrator, setting forth the name, address,
telephone number and other applicable information as may be prescribed. Upon
payment of the business parking permit fee, the Village Administrator shall
issue the permit.
   D.   Permit Fee: The business parking permit fee shall be paid on a
semiannual basis in an amount of two hundred ten dollars. The fee for Special
Permit Parking Zone A shall be paid on an annual basis in an amount of four
hundred eighty dollars. Unused permits are not refundable.
   E.   Regulations For Use: It shall be unlawful and a violation of this
section to park any vehicle in a business parking permit zone unless the
vehicle displays a valid parking permit as described in this section, and is
parked so that the vehicle does not occupy more than one designated parking
stall. (Ord. 3326, 4-26-2010, eff. 4-26-2010)
9-2-29: PARKING RESERVE FUNDS:
A parking reserve shall be established by the Village Finance Director to
accumulate funds for the purpose of maintaining and repairing Village owned
parking lots or acquiring property and developing additional Village owned
parking lots. This reserve shall consist of fifty percent of the annual revenue
collected from monthly permit fees in accordance with subsections
9-2-20D and 9-2-24D of this chapter; and thirty three and one-third percent of
the annual revenue collected from daily commuter fees in accordance with
subsections
9-2-20D and
9-2-25B of this chapter. (Ord. 3473, 1-14-2013)
9-2-30: OVERWEIGHT VEHICLES:
It shall be unlawful to drive on any street any motor vehicle with a weight,
including load, in excess of that permitted by the Illinois Vehicle Code for
driving on improved highways, or with a weight distributed in a manner not
conforming to such statute.
   A.   Authority Of Administrative Adjudication Hearing Officer: Any violation
of the Illinois Vehicle Code relating to "overweight vehicle", specifically
violations of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-100 et seq., and 5/3-401(d)
of the Illinois Vehicle Code, may be decided by the Administrative Adjudication
Hearing Officer as set forth in chapter 6 of this title.
   B.   Penalties For Overweight Vehicle Violations:
      1.   Whenever any vehicle is operated in violation of the provisions of
the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/15-111 and 5/3-401
(d), the owner or the driver of such vehicle shall be deemed guilty of such
violation and either the owner or the driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted
for such violation. Any person, firm or corporation who is convicted for a
violation of section 15-111, including, but not limited to, a maximum axle or
gross limit specified on a regulatory sign posted in paragraph (g) or (h) of
section 15-111, shall be fined according to the following schedule except for
weights of five thousand five hundred or more pounds overweight.
Weight Fine Administrative Fee Total
Weight                                      Fine    Administrative Fee Total
Up to and including 2,000 pounds overweight $ 50.00 $25.00             $ 75.00
From 2,001 through 2,500 pounds overweight  135.00  25.00              160.00
From 2,501 through 3,000 pounds overweight  165.00  25.00              190.00
From 3,001 through 3,500 pounds overweight  260.00  25.00              285.00
From 3,501 through 4,000 pounds overweight  300.00  25.00              325.00
From 4,001 through 4,500 pounds overweight  425.00  25.00              450.00
From 4,501 through 5,000 pounds overweight  475.00  25.00              500.00
From 5,001 through 5,500 pounds overweight  725.00  25.00              750.00
 
      2.   If a second division vehicle and load are operated within the
Village of River Forest and the required fees and taxes for the gross weight of
the vehicle and load have not been paid or the vehicle and load exceed the
registered gross weight for which the required fees and taxes have been paid by
two thousand one pounds or more, the operator or owner shall be fined as stated
in subsection A of this section. For any unregistered vehicle or vehicle
displaying expired registration, no fine shall exceed the actual cost of what
the appropriate registration for that vehicle and load should have been as
established in the table below.
The following are the registration fees for vehicles and loads as set forth
below:

9-2-5 of this title, the following are hereby declared one-way streets and
alleys in the Village:

thirty o'clock A.M. and four o'clock P.M. on school days.

between seven thirty o'clock A.M. and four o'clock P.M. on school days.

Harlem Avenue.

9-3-7: SCHEDULE 7, SPEED LIMITS:
It is hereby determined that the absolute maximum speed limit for a motor
vehicle in the Village shall be twenty five miles per hour on all streets,
except for the following:
 
Alleys                                                           10 mph
Harlem Avenue                                                    30 mph
Lake Street                                                      30 mph
North Avenue                                                     30 mph
Chicago Avenue between Thatcher Avenue and the Des Plaines River 35 mph
 
(Ord. 3113, 5-23-2005; amd. Ord. 3205, 8-13-2007)
9-3-8: SCHEDULE 8, NO LEFT TURNS:
Left turns are hereby prohibited on the following streets:
   BONNIE BRAE, northbound traffic where it intersects with North Avenue.
